title: Complaint filed on behalf of woman who gave birth in Chula Vista Border Patrol station
authors: Came To The San Diego Union-Tribune In March She Worked First On The Datawatch Team Before Taking On The Immigration Beat In August
summary:
A Guatemalan woman who gave birth in a Border Patrol station last month says agents ignored her requests for medical attention, leading to her partially giving birth while standing and clutching the side of a trash can, according to a complaint filed on her behalf Wednesday.
The woman’s version of the story, published in the complaint filed with the Department of Homeland Security office of the inspector general, is quite different from what U.S. Border Patrol agents said happened.

title: Coronavirus outbreak puts Christy Gardner’s Paralympic dream on hold in California
summary:
Christy Gardner received an opportunity earlier this year to live her dream of competing in the Paralympics in Tokyo later this summer.

summary:

title: Police investigate after man stabbed in Chula Vista
summary:
Police in Chula Vista are investigating after a 29-year-old man who may be homeless was stabbed at an encampment early Friday morning, a police official said.
About 4:30 a.m., city firefighters asked police for assistance as they tended to the victim at a site on Main Street less than half a mile east of Interstate 5, Lt. Henry Martin said.
Martin said the victim was stabbed in his torso and leg, and his injuries are not believed to be life-threatening.
He said the victim has not cooperated with authorities.
They believe that the man was attacked at a homeless encampment just south of Main Street, the lieutenant said.

title: Teen shot at Chula Vista birthday party
summary:
Gunfire that wounded a teenager in his arm broke up a birthday party at a Chula Vista home Saturday night, police said.
Some 60 to 70 young people at the party scattered at the sound of gunshots in the backyard of the Vista Way home about 8:40 p.m. , police said.
Medics took a 16-year-old to a hospital with a bullet wound to his arm.
Police said officers talked to a number of people who were at the house but no one could offer a description of the shooter.
Investigators planned on talking to the wounded victim as soon as he is well enough.

title: Chula Vista’s Otay Ranch among the top-selling developments last year
summary:

The large Otay Ranch development, close to the U.S.-Mexico border, is 25,000 acres and nearly the size of San Francisco.
Otay Ranch has made the list several times over the years, but this is its highest ranking.

title: Chula Vista firefighters attack blaze in historic home built in 1880s
summary:
Chula Vista firefighters battled a blaze early Monday morning at a historic home, built in the 1880s, near downtown, and one firefighter was treated for leg burns and has been released, authorities said.
A passing off-duty paramedic spotted the fire about 8:30 a.m. and called for help, Chula Vista Fire Capt.
The burning home was the historic Hancil Cordrey House located at 210 Davidson Street.
It is one of the few remaining original Victorian homes built during Chula Vista’s early development, according to the city.
Firefighters had not yet determined the cause of the fire early Monday morning.

title: School told to 'shelter in place' during gas leak
summary:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. — Students, teachers and staff at a high school in Chula Vista were told to shelter in place as authorities worked to cap a gas leak near the school, the City of Chula Vista said Thursday.
The leak was reported around noon in front of Eastlake High School in the Eastlake Greens neighborhood, according to the Chula Vista Fire Department.
Though city officials said the leak posed no immediate danger, Eastlake High School was told to shelter in place until further notice.
Officials said the gas line was damaged by a third party, but additional details surrounding the leak were not immediately available.

title: Sears in Chula Vista is shuttering next month, leaving only 2 locations in San Diego County
summary:
The Chula Vista Sears, one of the last remaining locations in San Diego County, is unloading all its stock as it prepares to shutter in February.
The only remaining Sears store in San Diego County is the one in Escondido at 210 E. Via Rancho Parkway, along with a Sears Outlet at 1210 W. Morena Boulevard.
The near-disappearance of Sears from San Diego County marks the end of a retail era.
Transformco bought 223 Sears stores and 202 Kmart locations out of bankruptcy for $5.2 billion.
After this round of closures, Transformco will operate 182 Kmart and Sears stores.

title: San Diego expected to be California’s ‘hottest’ home market in 2020, Zillow survey says
summary:
San Diego will be the hottest major home market for California in 2020, concludes a panel of experts in a Zillow study, but it won’t experience major gains as in past years.
They did not give an exact prediction of how much the median San Diego County home value would increase, which was about $600,650 as of November.
Instead, they rated the region on how likely it is to reach the national average of 2.8 percent.
While 39 percent of respondents thought San Diego County home values would under-perform compared to the national average, it was more extreme for other California markets.
Sixty-four percent predicted San Francisco would under-perform, 61 percent for San Jose, 55 percent in Los Angeles, 52 percent in Sacramento, and 47 percent in Riverside.

summary:

The shooting happened shortly before 10 p.m. west of Interstate 805 along Vista Way, according to the Chula Vista Police Department.

title: Storm to produce ‘rare and dangerous’ seas off Southern California this weekend
summary:
A large and fast-moving cold front will dive down the Southern California coastline on Sunday, producing 20-plus-foot waves and winds of 50 mph or higher in a “rare and dangerous” event in the outer waters, according to the National Weather Service.
Forecasters at the weather service’s Rancho Bernardo and Los Angeles-Oxnard offices said boaters should not venture beyond local harbors between Sunday afternoon and Monday night to avoid a lashing by gale force winds.
And it is possible that waves as high as 20 feet could appear within 20 miles of the San Diego County coastline.
A gale force warning will be in effect for the outer waters from 2 p.m. Sunday to 2 p.m. Monday.
AdvertisementStrong winds, choppy waves and vicious rip currents are expected along the immediate coast.

title: Chula Vista school, teacher housing bond measure lags behind passing margin
summary:
A Chula Vista school bond measure to build the first school district teacher housing project in San Diego County does not have enough votes to pass in unofficial returns.
The $300 million Measure M would build about 100 units of affordable housing for Chula Vista Elementary School District teachers and staff.
It takes a yearly salary of at least $122,646 to afford a median-priced single-family home in San Diego, while median monthly rent in San Diego is $2,600, according to Zillow.
A state law passed in 2016, the Teacher Housing Act, allows school districts to build affordable housing just for employees.
Measure M faced opposition from the San Diego County Taxpayers Association, which said there wasn’t enough evidence that Chula Vista needed teacher housing.

Two people died and at least two more were injured in a wrong-way crash that involved at least seven vehicles in the southbound lanes of Interstate 5 Saturday morning in Chula Vista, a California Highway Patrol officer said.
“We got a call about 5 a.m. of a black truck traveling the wrong way at high speed with no lights,” CHP Officer Jake Sanchez said.

As of 5:30 a.m., CHP had two lanes closed and expected traffic to remain partially blocked in the area for at least an hour.

title: Study: Chula Vista among worst US cities for commuters
summary:
SAN DIEGO (KGTV) -- Traffic is a nearly daily occurrence on San Diego County roads, but a new study has some particularly bad news for those who commute to work from Chula Vista.
According to financial technology company SmartAsset, the county’s second-largest city is the 19th-worst city in the U.S. for work commuters.
The study shows Chula Vista is actually tied with Oakland, but the Bay Area city is listed at 18th.
After analyzing 100 U.S. cities, SmartAsset compiled statistics from the following metrics:-- Average commute (in minutes)-- 5-year change in the average commute-- Percent of workers with a commute over 60 minutes-- Median income-- 5-year change in median incomeCheck 10News TrafficThe report shows the average Chula Vista resident’s work commute is 30.9 minutes.
The city has seen a 15.3% increase when it comes to the 5-year change in the average commute.

title: Chula Vista school district wants to build affordable housing for teachers
summary:
Chula Vista Elementary School District is asking voters to approve a bond measure that would build 100 units of affordable housing for its teachers and staff.
Teacher housing is an idea gaining interest around the country with school districts grappling with housing affordability problems and teacher shortages.
A state law passed in 2016, the Teacher Housing Act, allows districts to provide affordable housing just for educators and staff.
AdvertisementChula Vista district officials say they hope affordable housing will attract and keep more teachers.
Skala said the union also supports the affordable housing project because a district staff survey last year found that hundreds of staff want district housing.

title: Driver leads Chula Vista police on pursuit, crashes in Spring Valley
summary:
A driver pulled over for a traffic violation — who was wanted on two felony warrants —led Chula Vista police on a chase early Monday before crashing his car in the La Presa area of Spring Valley.
Chula Vista officers pulled the man over for having tinted windows on his BMW shortly after 3:45 a.m. on Birch Street and Millenia Avenue and were running his registration when they noticed something that looked like a meth pipe in the car, said Chula Vista police Lt. Frank Giaime.
The driver started his car and took off, leading officers on a pursuit on northbound state Route 125, hitting speeds of up to 100 mph at times.
He is in his 40s and was being sought on two felony warrants, Giaime said.
He suffered minor injuries in the crash and was taken to the hospital to be evaluated.

title: Maroon 5 to open 2020 North American tour in San Diego. Here are all the dates and ticket info
summary:
The group, led by lead singer and former “The Voice” TV show judge Adam Levine, will kick off its 2020 North American amphitheater and stadium tour May 30 at North Island Credit Union Amphitheatre in Chula Vista, just south of San Diego.
All tour dates appear below, along with ticket information.
Meghan Trainor will be the opening act on all dates, while neo-soul vocal dynamo Leon Bridges will be added for the stadium shows.
Tickets for the tour will go on sale to the general public on Dec. 13 at livenation.com and ticketmaster.com.
Ticket prices for the May 30 tour-opening show in Chula Vista range from $39.50 to $149.50 each, plus service charges.

title: Chula Vista Teacher Salary Negotiations Stalled Over Class-Size Issue
summary:
Salary negotiations between Chula Vista teachers and the school district are a standstill over the central issue of class sizes.
Teachers across the Chula Vista Elementary School District demonstrated on Wednesday after school in a walkout, protesting the district’s latest counteroffer to pay for salary and benefit increases by removing a cap on individual class size.
Right now, class sizes for grades 4 through 6 are capped at 31 students.
Under the district's proposal, class sizes in these grades would have to average 31 students per site.
“In instruction alone, it’ll hurt in the primary grades in getting reading instruction,” said Meg Rabine, a teacher at Clear View Elementary School.

summary:

The crash happened around 12:40 a.m. near the intersection of Telegraph Canyon Road and Paseo Ranchero, police say.
According to police, the driver of a Scion TC was traveling west on Telegraph Canyon Road when they rear ended a police vehicle before slamming into a Honda CRV stopped in the left turn pocket.

title: Museum exhibit to feature Holocaust survivors who settled in South Bay
summary:
The Chula Vista Heritage Museum on Sunday will unveil a year-long exhibit titled “RUTH: Remembering Us The Holocaust,” which will feature the stories of Holocaust survivors who settled in the South Bay.
The title pays tribute to one survivor in particular: Ruth Sax, who survived three Nazi concentration camps.
In the South Bay, Sax devoted time to the community by speaking to local schools and Southwestern College.
The Heritage Museum is located in the Civic Center Branch Library, at 365 F Street.
Prior to the opening of the exhibit, at 11 a.m. Sunday, Mayor Mary Casillas Salas and survivors will host a brunch at the library.

title: Lane closures expected on I-805 through Valentine's Day
summary:
Starting this weekend, a freeway-improvement project will necessitate intermittent closures of sections of northbound I-805.
Additionally, crews will be working under Sweetwater River Bridge, posing delays for bicyclists on an adjacent bikeway, officials said.
The I-805 South Corridor Enhancement Projects include the addition of sound walls and safety improvements to Sweetwater River Bridge.
The improvements build on the I-805 South Express Lanes Project, a $1.4 billion effort to create a modern transportation backbone for southern San Diego County.
The changes are aimed at helping alleviate congestion, improving traffic flow and enhancing the quality of life for residents along the southern I-805 corridor.

title: Chula Vista adds more fees to open a marijuana business
summary:
Opening a marijuana business in Chula Vista just got more expensive.
The City Council recently approved five new application and regulatory fees, raising the costs to open a cannabis business from about $7,000 to at least $55,000.
AdvertisementThe city of Vista charges marijuana businesses more up front.
Chula Vista, which could become home to the largest marijuana market in San Diego County, is currently evaluating business license applications and has yet to issue any licenses.
In the first phase of the application process, applicants must show they have at least $250,000 in liquid assets.

summary:
More than a year after Chula Vista began processing marijuana business license applications, the results are starting to come in.
On Jan. 14, the City Council made it easier for some of those rejected applicants to reapply.
AdvertisementThe council unanimously approved eliminating a one-year waiting period before reapplying for cannabis business licenses.
Chula Vista legalized the sale of adult-use cannabis in March 2018 and voters approved a cannabis sales tax in October of that same year.
The rules also prohibit anyone connected with illegal dispensaries from obtaining a cannabis business license in the city.

title: Chula Vista Elementary Teachers Get Pay Bump Without Class-Size Increase
summary:
The Chula Vista Elementary School District has agreed to a tentative contract with its teachers' union that does not include class-size increases.
The district will also increase its contribution to teacher health benefits by $1,000 per teacher between now and January 2021.
The teachers union will vote to ratify the agreement by March 20.
The district said the class-size increases were needed to offset the costs of the bump in pay and benefits.
Susan Skala, president of Chula Vista Educators, said she expects the tentative agreement will be ratified by the union.

summary:

The woman refused to be transported to the hospital at first, but later asked to be treated at a hospital.

title: San Diego will soon have rent control. What renters and landlords need to know
summary:
Rent control is coming to San Diego County in 2020, and there is a lot for tenants and landlords to know.
Rent is now cappedLandlords cannot raise rent more than 5 percent plus inflation as of Jan. 1.
AdvertisementFiguring out what the inflation rate is can take some work for landlords, and renters who want to make sure they are not being overcharged.
The inflation rate is based on the California Consumer Price Index published by the state’s Department of Industrial Relations.
However, it is pretty rare for the average rent in San Diego County to go up more than 7 percent.

title: Harbor police rescue man, woman clinging to kayak near Chula Vista marina
summary:
Harbor police officers on Friday evening rescued a man and woman who fell into the San Diego Bay and were clinging to their kayak near a Chula Vista marina, a sergeant said.
A 911 caller alerted San Diego Harbor Police at 5:30 p.m. that there were people in the water near the Chula Vista boat ramp and yacht marina, Harbor police Sgt.
Authorities later learned that the friends, a man and a woman, had paddled out in a two-seater kayak, but lost control of the vessel about 20 to 30 yards from shore, Morris said.

He has beautiful hair,” Harden told the Union-Tribune.

title: Chula Vista sets out to collect taxes from short-term rentals
summary:
The city of Chula Vista has made progress in enforcing regulations that require short-term rentals to pay taxes, collecting more than $30,000 in taxes from 95 rentals in the past six months.
To enforce its regulations, the city contracted with Host Compliance, which offers short-term rental monitoring services.
The notices informed individuals that through the partnership with Host Compliance, individuals can now register their rentals and pay taxes online.

title: Developers wants to build 700 housing units next to Otay Landfill

A Chula Vista developer wants to turn 54 acres of undeveloped land next to the Otay Landfill into 700 housing units.
Sunbow LLC, the developer who has owned the space since 1989, wants Chula Vista to rezone the land because they say there is no market for industrial properties there.

Sunbow’s plan is to build 700 residential units and set aside 8 acres for commercial use.

title: Researchers Find Coronavirus Arrived in New York from Europe in Mid-February
summary:
Medical researchers say the novel coronavirus likely circulated undetected for weeks in New York beginning in February — long before New York confirmed its first COVID-19 case on March 1.
Two separate teams of researchers say genetic material taken from thousands of patients shows the main source of early infections came from Europe, and not from Asia.
The finding undermines President Trump’s argument that his ban on travelers from China in late January delayed the arrival of the coronavirus in the U.S.
It also underscores how a critical lack of testing laid the seeds for an explosion of COVID-19 illnesses and deaths in New York and beyond.
Meanwhile, the National Academy of Sciences warns the spread of the coronavirus is unlikely to slow as springtime temperatures return to the Northern Hemisphere.

When you look at the numbers on the death toll, it has been going steadily up, and it reached a new height yesterday.”Governor Cuomo acknowledged the true death toll is certain to be higher because hundreds of people who’ve died of COVID-19 in their homes have not been counted.

Pension obligation bonds, Bilby said, could stabilize that CalPERS payment by decreasing the interest rateS, which are currently at 7 percent.

title: Editorial: Chula Vista shouldn’t gamble on pension bonds
summary:
Pension obligation bonds have a terrible track record in California.
Despite this history and that description, at a recent Chula Vista City Council meeting, city Finance Director David Bilby depicted the bonds as a pragmatic way for the city reduce the long-term costs of paying its unfunded pension liability of $355 million.
AdvertisementIf Chula Vista wants to reduce pension costs, it should avoid gimmicks.
City leaders could build on modest pension reforms and reduce benefits for new hires.
There is an argument that that would make the city less attractive to municipal workers, but city liabilities wouldn’t soar — which is what happens when pension obligation bonds go horribly wrong.

title: Man convicted of murder in Chula Vista road rage stabbing sentenced to 16 years to life -
summary:
CHULA VISTA (KUSI) – A 61-year-old man who fatally stabbed another motorist on a South Bay roadway following a road rage dispute has been sentenced to 16 years to life in state prison.
Rickey Vernon Smith, 61, was convicted last fall of second-degree murder for the Nov. 27, 2018, slaying of 36-year-old Horace Williams Jr., a father of five.
Deputy District Attorney Makenzie Harvey alleged that after cutting Williams off for the final time, Smith got out of his truck, walked up to Williams’ driver’s side window and punched him.
Smith told the dispatcher that he followed Williams to find out why he did that, then later admitted to punching and stabbing Williams.
Smith said in the call that it was Williams who did the punching and that he stabbed Williams in self- defense, to prevent further punching.

title: Crews keep an eye on Otay Mesa auto wrecking yard where fire burned for hours
summary:
A San Diego Fire-Rescue engine and truck remained at an auto wrecking yard near the airport in Otay Mesa early Thursday to make sure that a fire that engulfed rows of junked vehicles Wednesday didn’t reignite.
The fire was reported about 3:15 p.m. on Datsun Street near Otay Valley Road, just west of Brown Field Municipal Airport, according to the San Diego Fire-Rescue Department.
“It’s a slow overhaul operation.”AdvertisementAs the fire burned, authorities had shut down a section of Datsun Street fronting the junkyard along with stretches of nearby Heritage Road, Otay Mesa Road and Otay Valley Road, according to San Diego police.

title: Sears in Chula Vista is shuttering next month, leaving only 2 locations in San Diego County
summary:
The Chula Vista Sears, one of the last remaining locations in San Diego County, is unloading all its stock as it prepares to shutter in February.
The only remaining Sears store in San Diego County is the one in Escondido at 210 E. Via Rancho Parkway, along with a Sears Outlet at 1210 W. Morena Boulevard.
The near-disappearance of Sears from San Diego County marks the end of a retail era.
Transformco bought 223 Sears stores and 202 Kmart locations out of bankruptcy for $5.2 billion.
After this round of closures, Transformco will operate 182 Kmart and Sears stores.

title: Tijuana cops charged in Chula Vista home burglary
summary:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. — Two Tijuana police officers are among six people accused of taking part in a break-in at a Chula Vista home because they believed there would be $1 million in cash to steal from the residence, prosecutors said Wednesday.
Marco Quijas-Castillo, 27, and Jesus Estrada Torres, 34, are charged with conspiracy to commit robbery and conspiracy to commit burglary for allegedly providing “counter-surveillance” for their four co-defendants as they met with an undercover FBI agent in Chula Vista.
The officers allegedly also kept watch outside the Chula Vista home, while one co-defendant worked to break in, according to the San Diego County District Attorney’s Office.
The two officers, along with Igancio Martinez-Cruz, 33, Mario Eugene Hall, 34, Tomas Emmanuel Ramirez, 29, and Nicholas Jeremiah Shaw, 24, were arraigned Tuesday at the Chula Vista courthouse.
Castillo and Torres “provided counter-surveillance” at a Kohl’s store in Chula Vista, while the other four men met with an undercover agent, the complaint alleges.

summary:

Jones said no guns were fired, and the man surrendered without incident.

title: Felon sleeping in car with BB rifle arrested at Chula Vista strip mall
summary:
Chula Vista police on Saturday surrounded and arrested a man who was sleeping in his car next to a realistic-looking BB rifle while parked at a strip mall, authorities said.
Customers and employees were told to stay indoors as officers trained rifles on the car and moved a Bearcat armored vehicle in front of the man’s black Chrysler 300 sedan.
The 29-year-old man woke up and surrendered peacefully, police said.
The man was still asleep as officers moved in with rifles aimed at the car windows and the Bearcat moved into place.
AdvertisementWhen the man woke up, on his own, he obeyed orders to put his raised hands out of the car.

title: Sears Chula Vista to Close Its Doors This Month
summary:
The Sears store in Chula Vista will be closing its doors this month, joining more than a dozen Sears locations closing across California.
Transformco, the parent company that owns Sears and Kmart, gave NBC7 the following statement on Tuesday, in response to the closure:"After careful review, we have made the difficult but necessary decision to close the Sears store in Chula Vista, California.
The liquidation sale is in process and the store is planned to close in mid-February.
The initial news that the Chula Vista Sears location off Broadway would be closing was announced last November.
On Sears’ website, there are four Sears locations left in San Diego County.

title: Person back in ICE custody after being evaluated for coronavirus at Sharp Chula Vista
summary:
SAN DIEGO (KGTV) -- A person is back in ICE custody and in isolation after they were taken to Sharp Chula Vista Medical Center to be evaluated for possible coronavirus symptoms.
The individual was in the custody of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement when officials determined the person needed to be taken to Sharp Chula Vista, the county said.
RELATED:Because the person was in ICE custody, the hospital returned the individual to the agency on Wednesday and the person was placed in isolation.
Medical professionals at ICE detention facilities medically screen all new ICE detainees within 24 hours of their arrival to ensure that contagious diseases are not spread throughout the facility, and elsewhere.
As an additional measure of defense, ICE detainees suspected of exposure or infection of certain diseases are medically 'cohorted,' in line with CDC guidelines and ICE detention standards."

title: New satellite voting locations opening around San Diego County on Saturday
summary:
SAN DIEGO (KGTV) -- The San Diego Registrar of Voters is opening satellite locations throughout the county that will allow residents to cast their votes starting Feb. 29.
The five locations will be available from Saturday, Feb. 29, through Election Day (March 3), and include the Registrar of Voter’s office in Kearny Mesa in addition to four locations in San Marcos, Carmel Mountain Ranch, Spring Valley, and Chula Vista.
The new locations are in place due to long lines at the Registrar’s Office that wrapped around the building during the last election.
All the satellite locations will be open from 8 a.m. through 5 p.m. from Saturday, Feb. 29 through Monday, March 2, and 7 a.m. to 8 p.m. on Election Day.
See a list of locations below:San Marcos3 Civic Center DriveSan Marcos, CA 92069Carmel Mountain Ranch10152 Rancho Carmel DriveSan Diego, CA 92128Spring Valley8735 Jamacha Blvd.

title: Sweetwater school board votes to put more than 200 employees on notice
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoCHULA VISTA, Calif. -- Board members with the Sweetwater Union High School District voted 3-2 Monday night to put more than 200 employees on notice.
School district administrators said Monday the potential cuts are necessary because of budget shortfalls, declining enrollment and increasing personnel costs.
Hubner told FOX 5 she has been with the school district for 17 years but could soon be one of the 237 employees who will be cut.
"It is universally felt that it is heartbreak," Hubner said when asked how other school employees were feeling.
Not a single speaker was in favor of cutting the jobs in question, but the school board ultimately still voted 3-to-2 in favor of the cuts.

title: Chula Vista seeks funding for 200 affordable housing units
summary:
Chula Vista wants to help bring 200 units of affordable housing and another pedestrian footbridge to Otay Ranch.
Last week, the City Council voted unanimously to present a joint application with a housing developer to get up to $30 million in state funding.
That funding, through the state’s Affordable Housing and Sustainable Communities program, is specifically for housing and infrastructure projects.
The city would like to build a footbridge at Hunte Parkway that would complement the Eastlake Parkway Bridge, which is currently under construction.
The idea of a Hunte Parkway bridge has been around for a couple of years.

title: SUV leads 90-minute pursuit through LA
summary:
The chase began about 4:50 p.m. near Workman Mill Road and Rio Hondo College in Whittier, Deputy Eric Ortiz said.
Deputies from the Pico Rivera station responded to a report of a possible assault at or near Rose Hills Cemetery in Whittier and saw a black SUV they believed might have been involved, Ortiz said.
Deputies tried to pull the vehicle over, but the driver allegedly pointed a gun at the sheriff's cruiser and sped off, triggering the pursuit, he said.
During the chase, a passenger exited the SUV and ran through an intersection in an escape attempt.
About 6:20 p.m., he returned to the Pico Rivera area and lost control of the SUV, apparently disabling it, and requiring him and his remaining passenger to hop out.

title: Chula Vista Elementary Teachers Get Pay Bump Without Class-Size Increase
summary:
The Chula Vista Elementary School District has agreed to a tentative contract with its teachers' union that does not include class-size increases.
The district will also increase its contribution to teacher health benefits by $1,000 per teacher between now and January 2021.
The teachers union will vote to ratify the agreement by March 20.
The district said the class-size increases were needed to offset the costs of the bump in pay and benefits.
Susan Skala, president of Chula Vista Educators, said she expects the tentative agreement will be ratified by the union.

The race for California endorsements has ratcheted up.

title: Lane closures expected on I-805 through Valentine's Day
summary:
Starting this weekend, a freeway-improvement project will necessitate intermittent closures of sections of northbound I-805.
Additionally, crews will be working under Sweetwater River Bridge, posing delays for bicyclists on an adjacent bikeway, officials said.
The I-805 South Corridor Enhancement Projects include the addition of sound walls and safety improvements to Sweetwater River Bridge.
The improvements build on the I-805 South Express Lanes Project, a $1.4 billion effort to create a modern transportation backbone for southern San Diego County.
The changes are aimed at helping alleviate congestion, improving traffic flow and enhancing the quality of life for residents along the southern I-805 corridor.

title: Storm to produce ‘rare and dangerous’ seas off Southern California this weekend
summary:
A large and fast-moving cold front will dive down the Southern California coastline on Sunday, producing 20-plus-foot waves and winds of 50 mph or higher in a “rare and dangerous” event in the outer waters, according to the National Weather Service.
Forecasters at the weather service’s Rancho Bernardo and Los Angeles-Oxnard offices said boaters should not venture beyond local harbors between Sunday afternoon and Monday night to avoid a lashing by gale force winds.
And it is possible that waves as high as 20 feet could appear within 20 miles of the San Diego County coastline.
A gale force warning will be in effect for the outer waters from 2 p.m. Sunday to 2 p.m. Monday.
AdvertisementStrong winds, choppy waves and vicious rip currents are expected along the immediate coast.

title: Chula Vista considers banning all flavored tobacco products
summary:
Chula Vista’s vape shop owners successfully stopped a proposed ban on the sale of flavored tobacco products in the county’s second-largest city.
AdvertisementBoth of those ideas seemed to resonate with the City Council.
Representatives from the American Lung Association, American Heart Association and American Cancer Society all supported the proposed flavored tobacco ban because it would reduce youth access.
“As long as flavored products are still available, kids will continue to use them and get hooked,” said Chelsea Walczack Vircks of the American Heart Association of San Diego.
Ultimately, the City Council asked for more information before making a decision.

title: Man dies after attack in Vista intersection; four sought
summary:
A man died after being attacked by three men and a woman in an intersection in Vista Saturday night, sheriff’s officials said.
His name and age were not released.
Officials said witnesses told deputies the victim had been attacked by three men and a woman, all believed to be in their 20s.
The men were wearing dark clothing and the woman was in a gray sweatshirt.
AdvertisementThe sheriff’s homicide unit asked anyone with any information about the attack to call (858) 285-6330.

title: Chula Vista included on Sears’ latest store closures list
summary:
The new closures will affect a handful of stores in Southern California, including one located at 565 Broadway in Chula Vista.
Following the closures, the company will operate just 182 stores, down from nearly 700 when it filed for bankruptcy in October of last year.
"We will continue to evaluate our Sears and Kmart footprint, consistent with our overall retail and service strategy," Transformco said in a statement Thursday.
Earlier this year, the company had closed or said it would close around 90 Sears and Kmart stores.
For this latest round of closures, going out of business sales are expected to begin on December 2.

title: These men are running to represent District 3 on Chula Vista’s City Council
summary:
Three candidates hoping to represent southeast Chula Vista on the City Council gave prospective voters a preview of how they would govern during a candidates forum last week.
The forum, sponsored by the Chula Vista Chamber of Commerce, featured District 3 incumbent Councilman Steve Padilla and his two challengers: Doug Wolf, owner of the Chula Vista Mathnasium, and retired Navy veteran Henry Martinez.

title: Man stabbed at site of shuttered Vista restaurant
summary:
Two people were arrested on suspicion of stabbing a man at the closed Town Hall Public House in Vista on Wednesday afternoon.
Lt. Ted Greenawald of the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department said a call came in about a stabbing at the restaurant site, 230 S. Santa Fe Ave., at about 4:40 p.m. Two men were seen running toward the back of Smitty’s Bar on Broadway, and deputies arrested them at the nearby Sprinter station.
Greenawald said there was no information on the condition of the man who was stabbed.
The restaurant closed about two weeks ago.
It had opened last August after its owners re-branded what had been the Flying Pig Pub and Kitchen, which opened at the site about five years ago.

title: Chula Vista school district wants to build affordable housing for teachers
summary:
Chula Vista Elementary School District is asking voters to approve a bond measure that would build 100 units of affordable housing for its teachers and staff.
Teacher housing is an idea gaining interest around the country with school districts grappling with housing affordability problems and teacher shortages.
A state law passed in 2016, the Teacher Housing Act, allows districts to provide affordable housing just for educators and staff.
AdvertisementChula Vista district officials say they hope affordable housing will attract and keep more teachers.
Skala said the union also supports the affordable housing project because a district staff survey last year found that hundreds of staff want district housing.

title: Federal investigators sent to scene of bus crash that killed 3, left 17 hospitalized
summary:
The National Transportation Safety Board sent a team to investigate Saturday’s charter bus crash off Interstate 15 that killed three passengers and left 17 hospitalized, the federal agency said Sunday.
The crash occurred amid rainy conditions when the driver swerved and lost control of the bus in the southbound lanes of the freeway about 10:20 a.m.
The bus driver, a 52-year-old man from Whittier who suffered minor scrapes and complained of pain, is cooperating in the ongoing investigation.
He voluntarily submitted a blood sample, though the CHP said neither drugs nor alcohol were suspected factors in the crash.
A heavy-duty tow truck hauled the bus up the embankment and it was taken to a CHP evidence yard.

title: Pete Buttigieg Holding Last Rally Before Super Tuesday at San Ysidro High School
summary:
By Ken StoneShare This Article:Presidential candidate Pete Buttigieg will hold a get-out-the-vote rally Monday night at San Ysidro High School — not in Chula Vista as previously signaled.

title: San Diego expected to be California’s ‘hottest’ home market in 2020, Zillow survey says
summary:
San Diego will be the hottest major home market for California in 2020, concludes a panel of experts in a Zillow study, but it won’t experience major gains as in past years.
They did not give an exact prediction of how much the median San Diego County home value would increase, which was about $600,650 as of November.
Instead, they rated the region on how likely it is to reach the national average of 2.8 percent.
While 39 percent of respondents thought San Diego County home values would under-perform compared to the national average, it was more extreme for other California markets.
Sixty-four percent predicted San Francisco would under-perform, 61 percent for San Jose, 55 percent in Los Angeles, 52 percent in Sacramento, and 47 percent in Riverside.

title: 2 stabbings reported within 10 minutes downtown
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoSAN DIEGO -- A woman stabbed a man with a knife during an argument at a trolley station downtown Saturday night just minutes after an unrelated stabbing was reported a few blocks away, authorities said.
Police initially said the first stabbing happened at 8:32 p.m. along the 1500 block of Commercial Street but later said it happened near 10 24th Street.
The second stabbing happened about nine minutes later at the trolley station along the 1200 block of Imperial Street.
San Diego police told FOX 5 a 23-year-old man was arguing with his girlfriend near the trolley station when a 21-year-old woman approached them.
The woman pushed the man while trying to break up the couple's argument and the man punched her.

title: Newsom Orders All Californians to Stay Home
summary:
The order exempts businesses and agencies that provide essential services, like grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations and doctor’s offices, or are considered critical infrastructure.
The move added a level of consistency to restrictions that have been enacted piecemeal over the last several days across the state.
In large swaths of California, “nonessential” businesses like movie theaters, gyms and bars had already been ordered to close.
And state officials had already urged residents 65 and older or with chronic health conditions to stay at home.
Other communities followed, adopting almost identical orders or measures with slight variations.

title: San Diego County shaken by a 4.9 earthquake on a dangerous fault near Anza
summary:
San Diego County was shaken hard Friday evening by a 4.9 earthquake that broke near Anza.
The quake erupted along the San Jacinto fault system, which scientists say is capable of producing a 7.3 to 7.5 temblor.
“This was a moderate earthquake in an area that has produced a lot of moderate earthquakes,” said Tom Rockwell, a San Diego State University scientist who has studied the San Jacinto system for years.
It produced up to 13 feet of lateral displacement near Anza.”The average return time of a big quake in that area is 270 years.

title: ‘It would be heartbreaking’: Teens fear they may lose prom, graduation and rest of senior year
summary:
Karolyn and other high school seniors say they are coming to the realization that their schools may not re-open this spring and they may lose the rest of their senior year.
“It’s just crazy to think it’s all over, or it could be all over,” said Carlos Torres, an 18-year-old senior and student body president at Bonita Vista High School in Chula Vista.
The loss of school will impact all students academically and socially, but it will have an extra emotional impact on many high school seniors.
Many say they were looking forward to prom, grad nite and an in-person, pomp-and-circumstance, walk-the-stage graduation ceremony — all the traditional rites of passage.
I don’t know if I’ll have a graduation,” said Jaden Chavez, a senior at Rancho Buena Vista High School in Vista.

title: San Diego-area cities consider service cuts, layoffs after pandemic causes sharp drops in tax revenue
summary:
Shrinking tax revenue during the COVID-19 pandemic is creating large deficits in the budgets of all 18 cities in San Diego County, officials say.
Typically economic downturns are most crushing for cities that rely heavily on volatile sales tax revenue, because a downturn usually cuts into car purchases, mall shopping and other activity that generates significant sales tax revenue.
The city of San Diego estimates its revenues will drop $109 million this spring: $83 million from hotel tax and $26 million from sales tax.
“Make no mistake, these are going to be some of the most significant cutbacks in San Diego history,” Faulconer said.

summary:
A 56-year-old man died at a hospital early Friday after struggling with Chula Vista police officers who responded to a call that he was trying to hurt himself by jumping from a second story window, police said.
An ensuing struggle left two officers with minor injuries, according to Collum and Lt Dan Peak.
Paramedics reported that Nunis became unresponsive in the ambulance and they attempted life-saving measures while driving him to a hospital, according to Collum.
Peak said five officers responded to the call, but only two were involved in the struggle and restraint of Nunis.

title: San Diego expected to be California’s ‘hottest’ home market in 2020, Zillow survey says
summary:
San Diego will be the hottest major home market for California in 2020, concludes a panel of experts in a Zillow study, but it won’t experience major gains as in past years.
They did not give an exact prediction of how much the median San Diego County home value would increase, which was about $600,650 as of November.
Instead, they rated the region on how likely it is to reach the national average of 2.8 percent.
While 39 percent of respondents thought San Diego County home values would under-perform compared to the national average, it was more extreme for other California markets.
Sixty-four percent predicted San Francisco would under-perform, 61 percent for San Jose, 55 percent in Los Angeles, 52 percent in Sacramento, and 47 percent in Riverside.

title: Chula Vista sets out to collect taxes from short-term rentals
summary:
The city of Chula Vista has made progress in enforcing regulations that require short-term rentals to pay taxes, collecting more than $30,000 in taxes from 95 rentals in the past six months.
To enforce its regulations, the city contracted with Host Compliance, which offers short-term rental monitoring services.
The notices informed individuals that through the partnership with Host Compliance, individuals can now register their rentals and pay taxes online.
While the city and Host Compliance can track short-term rentals advertised online, there’s no way for them to know if a home is actually rented.

title: County announces 5 additional coronavirus cases, bans large gatherings amid coronavirus pandemic
summary:
The number of people in San Diego County with probable COVID-19 cases grew from one to seven Thursday, as county officials announced they will follow the state’s lead and ban all gatherings of 250 or more people.
Like most public health officials in her position, Wooten did not proactively close local K-12 schools.
He added that city and county officials are paying close attention to the homeless, as they consider individuals most at risk of infection.
The goal, Fletcher said, is to “slow down infection, rates of new cases, not only to protect public health, but protect our public health system.”Places of worship are likely to be among the hardest hit by the new limits on gatherings.
Officials said that city, county, state and medical officials are in constant communication about the outbreak, and updating plans based on a situation that changes hourly.

title: 1 Person Dead, Children Injured in Crash in Chula Vista: CVPD
summary:
One person has died and four others, including children, were injured in a crash involving a construction truck Monday in Chula Vista, the Chula Vista Police Department confirmed.
The construction truck caused a chain-reaction crash at about 1:10 p.m. on Fourth Avenue near Shasta Street.
The construction truck hit a black pick-up truck causing the pick-up truck to hit a man walking in the street, killing him, CVPD said.
Police said two children were inside or near the black pick-up truck when it was hit and were taken to area hospitals with minor injuries.
The person driving the construction truck appeared to be OK and is cooperating with officials.

title: Crash Kills Driver Who Led Police on Chase Through Chula Vista
summary:
A driver who led police on a short pursuit in Chula Vista Wednesday died in a crash that also injured two of his passengers.
The driver was identified on Friday as 32-year-old Chula Vista resident, Alfonso Huizar.
Huizar crashed his Mercedes station wagon near Hilltop Drive and Oxford Street just before 8 p.m., according to the Chula Vista Police Department.
Police attempted to pull the Mercedes over for driving without headlights, but Huizar did not stop, according to CVPD.
A loaded semi-automatic handgun was found inside the station wagon, according to CVPD.

title: Chula Vista City Council puts plan to make granny flats more affordable on hold
summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoCHULA VISTA, Calif. -- The City of Chula Vista was prepared to take action at Tuesday's special meeting, making granny flats more affordable and accessible to the public, but decided to put those plans on hold due to a bill making its way to the governor's desk.
Chula Vista residents spoke out at the meeting, making it clear that they’d like to see some changes in the process and cost to build an accessory dwelling unit, also known as a granny flat.
"I will have to say that the cost of the impact fees along with just fees and themselves are very, very high," one resident said.
"We were thinking about building a unit for my parents of $100,000 but it’s $25,000 in impact fees," said another man.
The Chula Vista City Council is set to meet again on October 22, and its members are hoping the governor will have signed the bill by then.

Crews arrived to find the double-wide trailer fully engulfed in flames.
Firefighters were able to extinguish the fire before it spread to homes nearby.
The man who was living in the home was taken to the UC San Diego Regional Burn Center for treatment of his injuries, according to Battalion Chief Brendan Barahura with the Chula Vista Fire Department.

Alfonso Huizar, 32 of Chula Vista, sped off and led officers on a pursuit southbound through Chula Vista before eventually reaching Hilltop Drive, where he lost control of the car near Oxford Street and slammed into a retaining wall and a telephone pole, Del Rio said.
The driver was pronounced dead and the two passengers were treated for minor injuries, Del Rio said.
Both arrestees’ names and ages were not immediately available, but Del Rio said they were documented gang members.

title: Jurors Reach Verdict in Deadly Chula Vista Road Rage Stabbing
summary:
A man accused of stabbing a father of five to death in a road rage attack in Chula Vista last year was found guilty of second degree murder Friday afternoon.
Smith stabbed Williams on the bridge between Chula Vista and Bonita just after 9 a.m. on Nov. 27, 2018.
Investigators said that as the dispute escalated, Smith pulled up alongside Williams and allegedly threw a soda at him.
Moments later, Smith pulled in front of Williams' van and slammed on his brakes, causing Williams to rear-end him, according to police.
The knife was found on Smith’s belt when officers arrived on the scene, said Chula Vista Police.

title: October goes out with a brrr!: Record cold in San Diego
summary:
A strange weather month in San Diego came to a chilly end on Thursday with the second-lowest temperature ever recorded in October and the coldest reading during the month in 48 years.
The mercury dropped to 44 degrees shortly after 7 a.m. at San Diego International Airport, site of the city’s official weather station.
By late Wednesday night, the winds had died down at the coast, and the cold air sank.
Just a week earlier, San Diego hit 94 degrees — the highest temperature of the year.
The weather service expects the cool nights to continue at the coast, with San Diego likely dipping into the 40s again Friday morning.

title: San Diego will soon have rent control. What renters and landlords need to know
summary:

The inflation rate is based on the California Consumer Price Index published by the state’s Department of Industrial Relations.

title: Christopher Columbus statue in Chula Vista park is vandalized again
summary:
A Christopher Columbus statue in a Chula Vista park that was vandalized in February was targeted again Monday — this time, on the federal holiday.
Around 7:50 a.m., a Chula Vista police officer discovered that the statue in Discovery Park on Buena Vista Way had splashes of red paint on it, Chula Vista police Capt.
Because they didn’t have a ladder that was tall enough, workers who initially cleaned the bronze likeness had to leave some of the red paint on the top of Columbus’ head.
On Feb. 24, red paint was poured on the statue’s head, someone painted “genocide” on the base and stole the statue’s plaque.
The statue was repaired when a worker welded the right leg back together.

title: 1 Stabbed, 1 Injured In Attack Near Chula Vista Intersection
summary:
CHULA VISTA, CA — One man was stabbed in the abdomen and another man suffered a minor laceration Wednesday morning when they were attacked by two groups of men from two separate cars after getting into an argument near a Chula Vista intersection, police said.
The altercation happened around 2 a.m. near Broadway and Flower Street, Chula Vista Police Lt. Scott Adkins said.
The two victims were walking northbound on Broadway when they got into an argument for unknown reasons with a motorist in a car near the intersection, Adkins said.
A fight ensued, during which one of the victims was stabbed in the lower abdomen and the other victim suffered a laceration to his abdomen, the lieutenant said.
No description of the suspects was immediately available, but the two cars were described as Volkswagen Jettas, one silver and one black.

title: One person dead and two others injured in Chula Vista police chase -

The Chula Vista Police Department said the suspect vehicle with three passengers inside crashed near Hilltop Drive and Oxford Street just before 8 p.m.
It started when a male driver of a Mercedes refused to pull over for a traffic violation.
The male driver was ejected, one female was knocked unconscious, and a male passenger was stunned and attempted to flee on foot.
All three passengers were transported to a local hospital, where the ejected male was in CPR status and died at the hospital.

title: Chula Vista is one of the most understaffed fire department in the state -
summary:
Chula Vista is one of the most understaffed fire department in the stateCHULA VISTA (KUSI) – Chula Vista is one of the most understaffed fire department in the state KUSI reporter John Soderman found out.
However a Chula Vista Fire Department battalion chief says the success in beating a recent blaze is because of a recently measure passed by voters which allowed each engine to have four firefighters as opposed to just three.

title: Year in Review: Top San Diego news stories of 2019
summary:
SAN DIEGO — With the new year quickly approaching, here’s a look back at some of our top stories from 2019.
February 18: Crews rescued 16 people after a ride at SeaWorld San Diego malfunctioned.
March 12: Dozens of San Diego parents were indicted for their alleged involvement in a nationwide college admission scandal.
The investigation — which continued throughout 2019 — involved alumni and aspiring student athletes at University of San Diego, UCLA, USC and several other prominent universities across the country.
June 28: A 2-year-old boy died following an E. coli infection linked to animals at the San Diego County Fair.

title: Chulafest will be held on Sunday, November 3 at the Chula Vista Community Park -
summary: Chulafest will be held on Sunday, November 3 at the Chula Vista Community ParkSAN DIEGO (KUSI) – Chula Vista’s Arts and Culture Director, Lynette Tesstorie and the API Initiative’s Co-Coordinator JoAnn Fields joins KUSI to discuss what can be expected at this year’s Chulafest.

title: 2 men attacked, stabbed at Chula Vista intersection
summary:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. (KGTV) -- Two men suffered stab wounds after being attacked at a Chula Vista intersection early Wednesday morning.
Chula Vista police said two men were at the intersection of Broadway and Flower Street at around 2 a.m. when they were stabbed by an unknown assailant.
One of the men was stabbed in his torso and taken to UC San Diego Medical Center.
His companion suffered minor injuries, police said.
According to police, two cars described as white Volkswagen Jettas were seen leaving the scene after the attack.

title: Brush fire scorches 10 acres near homes in Chula Vista south of San Miguel Mountain
summary:
A roughly 10-acre brush fire broke out Friday afternoon near homes in northeast Chula Vista at the southern foot of San Miguel Mountain, authorities said.
The blaze of unknown origin was reported about 4:50 p.m. off Agua Vista Drive, near a neighborhood of upscale homes east of the trail head to San Miguel Mountain, Chula Vista Deputy Fire Chief Harry Muns said.
Fire crews halted the spread of the blaze within about an hour, according to a tweet from the Chula Vista Fire Department.
Crews and resources from the San Diego Fire-Rescue Department and Cal Fire San Diego helped Chula Vista firefighters battle the blaze, according to Muns and Cal Fire spokesman Capt.
Cal Fire San Diego sent two water-dropping helicopters, among other resources, Shoots said.

title: California To Unveil Earthquake Alert System Thursday
summary:
Scientists cannot yet predict when the next deadly earthquake will strike, but emergency response authorities in California plan to unveil the first statewide quake warning system Thursday, which marks the 30th anniversary of the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake.
"The California Earthquake Early Warning System will marry a new smartphone application with traditional alert and warning delivery methods such as Wireless Emergency Alerts (WEA).
The California Earthquake Early Warning System is a joint project of the Office of Emergency Service, the U.S. Geological Service, UC Berkeley, CalTech, and others.
"The California Earthquake Early Warning System is based on innovative technology that will improve over time.
In rare circumstances, you may receive a ShakeAlert when there was no earthquake," the announcement of the system said.

title: Coastal Commission OKs permit to dismantle the San Onofre nuclear plant
summary:
SONGS is home to 3.55 million pounds of used-up nuclear fuel, between the Pacific and Interstate 5.
At the same time, Bochco said, “I feel little bit outraged that the federal government leaves us in this position.”AdvertisementThe San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station viewed from San Onofre State Beach on Thursday, October 17, 2019.
(Hayne Palmour IV/The San Diego Union-Tribune)Ultimately, the federal government has the final say about where used-up commercial nuclear fuel should go.
“The spent fuel pools should be on site as long as the fuel is on site,” said Torgen Johnson of the Del Mar-based Samuel Lawrence Foundation.
Members of the California Coastal Commission hear discussion on Oct. 17, 2019 about approving a permit to Southern California Edison to begin dismantling the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station.

title: Lime rolls out electric scooters in Chula Vista
summary:
Chula Vista is the latest city to test out electric scooters.
About 450 Lime scooters hit the streets across the city last weekend under a one-year pilot program.
A Lime spokesman said its fleet in Chula Vista will help the company, which has surpassed 4 million rides in the San Diego region, expand its network.
“We are excited to partner with the City of Chula Vista and provide mobility options for its residents,” said Kimia Talebien, Lime’s San Diego general manager.
The city and Lime representatives will host an event Sunday to demonstrate the scooters and offer riding and safety instructions.

title: Flu Deaths Of 2019-20 Season Begin In California
summary:
BAY AREA, CA — Two Santa Clara County residents, including a child, have died recently from the flu, county officials said Tuesday.
County public health officials do not know if either person received the flu vaccine, but said the deaths serve as a reminder of the importance of getting the flu vaccine.
The case is that county's first pediatric flu-related death of the 2019-2020 flu season, according to officials.
The man, whose name was withheld, also had additional medical issues, according to county health officials.
It was the county's first influenza death for the 2019-20 season.

title: California ignores the science as it OKs more homes in wildfire zones, researchers say
authors: Transportation For The San Diego Union-Tribune. He Writes About Everything Transit
Forest Management To The Science Of Climate Change. His Mission As A Journalist Is To Seek The Truth While Promoting The Health Of The Communities He Covers.
summary:
AdvertisementMore than 90% of fires in California are started by humans, often along roads and buildings lined with flammable invasive grasses.
Cal Fire has acknowledged that housing construction continues in and around the state’s wildlands, where about 11 million people now live in 4.5 million homes.
Hawks also downplayed the idea that building new homes in and around fire-prone areas would create more ignition sources, leading to more backcountry blazes.
When faced with public resistance, county lawmakers overseeing wildland areas often call on regional firefighting authorities to testify to the safety of specific projects.
Wildland fires that threaten people and homes in California are not the result of large forest fires.

title: Lime Launches Pilot Ride-Share Scooter Program in Chula Vista
summary:
The city of Chula Vista has launched a pilot ride-share program to bring Lime Scooters to the city for a one year test.
The pilot program will allow up to 500 dockless scooters to be placed around popular transit locations in Chula Vista within the first month of its launch.
"We're excited to bring mobility outside of San Diego into Chula Vista," said Matthew Anton, Operations Manager for Lime San Diego.
"This is my first time riding an electric scooter," said Norna Piggee, a resident of Chula Vista.
This pilot program comes after the city of San Diego initiated the process of revoking Lime's operation limit in August.

title: Today is hottest day of year in San Diego; Tuesday could match it
summary:
Today is the hottest day of 2019 in San Diego.
The mercury shot up to 88 degrees before noon on Monday at San Diego International Airport, site of San Diego’s official weather station.
By Friday, San Diego is expected to be back in the high 80s, with the valleys back in the 90s.
It’s not too unusual for San Diego to have its hottest days of the year in October.
Just two years ago, San Diego reached its max for the year on Oct. 25, when the high was 98.

title: Potentially dangerous Santa Ana winds expected to hit Southern California this week
summary:
The National Weather Service says that potentially dangerous Santa Ana winds will whip through much of Southern California later this week, raising the risk of wildfires in a region where large swaths of vegetation have withered away following winter rains, including inland San Diego County.
The winds also will snake into San Diego’s backcountry Thursday and Friday, when daytime highs are expected to climbed into the 80s and the relative humidity will fall to 10 to 12 percent in some areas.
“It looks like the winds will be stronger up north, but they’ll blow 20 to 30 mph here,” said Stephanie Sullivan, a forecaster at the weather service office in Rancho Bernardo.
AdvertisementSome of the worst wildfires in California history have occurred during the month of October, including the 2007 Witch Creek and Guejito fires in San Diego’s backcounty.
The fires, which merged, killed two people and destroyed more than 1,000 homes and businesses.

title: Evacuations lifted in Talmadge, Kensington after brush fire scorches canyons near homes
summary:
Within 25 minutes, San Diego police had ordered evacuations along Norma Drive, Constance Drive and Natalie Drive as the fire roared through canyons.
About 100 San Diego firefighters aggressively tackled the blaze as helicopters flew low over homes, repeatedly making water drops and dumping fire retardant.
(Hayne Palmour IV/The San Diego Union-Tribune)No structures were lost and no injuries were reported.
“It’s an extremely dangerous area,” San Diego Fire-Rescue Department Deputy Chief Steve Wright told OnScene TV.
Shortly after 2:30 p.m., San Diego fire officials announced on Twitter that forward progress on the south side of the fire had been halted.

summary:

Residents reported burning brush around 4 a.m., near a housing development along Village Drive and South Twin Oaks Valley Road just west of the Cal State San Marcos campus.
@CALFIRESANDIEGO is at scene with San Marcos Fire of a vegetation fire near Plateau Ave in the San Marcos area.

Around the county, more than 17,000 people were without power due to precautionary fire danger blackouts.

title: ‘It’s going to remain trying times’: Valley Center, Ramona spared major damage, but more winds coming
summary:
Sure enough, when her husband, Don, stepped outside their Valley Center home to investigate, he encountered an inferno across the road.
Temperatures were slightly cooler — still in the high 80s in Ramona and Valley Center — and winds were subdued, but Santa Ana winds were expected to return to the region by Monday.
All roads in Valley Center were reopened and residents were allowed to return to their homes Saturday morning.
Don Bohannon, whose Valley Center home was spared in the close-call, said he’s rarely ever worked as hard as he did for six consecutive hours Friday.
While temperatures are expected to remain in the 70s, it will be dry, with 5 to 10 percent humidity.

title: Sen. Elizabeth Warren to hold town hall in San Diego on Oct. 3
summary:
Sen. Elizabeth Warren will hold a town hall in San Diego on Oct. 3, marking her first visit to the city since kicking off her presidential campaign in February.
Her town hall will be at 7 p.m. at Waterfront Park in downtown San Diego, though doors will open at 5 p.m. It’s unknown how many people are expected to attend; the venue can hold thousands.
Despite her apparent surge, Warren has been absent from San Diego since announcing her candidacy.
Yet she has support in San Diego County, where her campaign garnered $87,601 in campaign contributions from 801 donors during the first six months of the year.
Those interested in attending Warren’s town hall can register through her campaign website.

title: Christopher Columbus statue in California found vandalized
summary:
CHULA VISTA, CA (KGTV) — A statue of Christopher Columbus standing at a Chula Vista park was vandalized on Columbus Day, police said.
This is why we have sent a letter to the City of Chula Vista to begin the process for the removal of the statue of Christopher Columbus and the renaming of the park.
A city spokesman issued the following statement: “City of Chula Vista crews are cleaning a statue of Christopher Columbus that was vandalized in Discovery Park over the weekend.
Additionally, the City has received a request to consider removing the statue and renaming Discovery Park.
The statue at Discovery Park was also vandalized with red paint in February.

title: Chula Vista’s New Dispatch Center Will Soon Allow 911 Texting
summary:
Chula Vista residents should expect better, faster service from first responders now that the Chula Vista Police Department has unveiled a larger 911 Emergency Communications Center with an upgraded 911 phone system.
“We have more dispatchers that will help us get those officers to them [residents] when they need help,” Kennedy said.
“I think the bigger the dispatch center, the better the ability that we have to help Chula Vista,” said police dispatcher Sarah McDonald.
The new center increases location accuracy for anyone who calls 911 and sets the department up for people to text emergencies to 911 in the future, CVPD said.
Chula Vista is the third city in the County to have the capability, but the entire county will need the capability before the system can go online.

title: Police Dog Sniffs Out Fentanyl, Cocaine During Traffic Stop In Chula Vista
summary:
Share This Article:A canine officer alerted authorities to nearly 600 counterfeit oxycodone pills and several grams of cocaine Wednesday during a traffic stop that was part of a narcotics interdiction operation, the San Diego County Sheriff’s Department said.
During the stop, the police dog indicated to the presence of narcotics.
Gomez, 21, was arrested and booked into the San Diego County Jail for felony transportation and sales of controlled substances.
A search of Gomez’s home yielded more of the pills like those seized from the car, along with about 1 ounce of cocaine.

title: Rumored Threat Prompts Extra Security at South Bay High School
summary:
Chula Vista police will have extra patrol at a South Bay high school on Thursday after a rumor of a threat that turned out not to be credible, according to school officials.
A message was sent to students and parents of Castle Park High School alerting them to a post circulating around social media about a shooting threat.
Sweetwater Union High School District (SUHSD) spokesperson Manny Rubio confirmed that the threat was not substantiated, and was actually a rumor of something that never occurred.
Despite, at least on Chula Vista patrol car was at the high school campus Thursday morning Rubio confirmed officers would be present at the school throughout the day.
Details may change as information is released.

title: Residents want to know why fish are dying in South Bay lake
summary:
“We noticed there was some dead fish floating – kind of an odd sight to see," said Justin McMillen.
Over the past couple weeks, people out for a relaxing stroll around the lake have also been counting dead fish.
HOA officials said that toxic soil may have created an algae bloom, sucking up the oxygen the fish need to survive.
Residents who enjoy the lake worry what it could mean for the rest of the wildlife here.
I’ve never seen dead fish, ever, in this lake," said Karen Brabandt.

title: Trial Begins Against Man Accused of Deadly Road Rage Stabbing
summary:
The murder trial for a man accused of stabbing a father of five to death in a road rage incident last year began in a South Bay courtroom Thursday morning.
Rickey Smith, 60, is accused of stabbing Horace Williams, 36, on the bridge between Chula Vista and Bonita just after 9 a.m. on November 27, 2018.
The man will stand trial for a deadly alleged road rage incident in Chula Vista.
NBC 7’s Bridget Naso has more.
A car crash in Chula Vista ended with one person being stabbed to death.

title: After mostly residential buildings, Chula Vista’s Millenia eyes first office project
summary:
After a flurry of mostly residential construction over the past five years, Chula Vista’s Millenia development is expected to see work begin soon on its first office buildings.
Chestnut Properties of Solana Beach has pulled building permits and is scheduled to break ground early next year on the Think office campus.
The 7-acre Think project includes two four-story buildings totaling 325,000 square feet, a 1,300 space parking garage and a fitness center/café complex.
To that end, the city council last year reduced Millenia’s retail and hotel blueprint while boosting office space planned for the development.
Housing will be intermixed with breweries, restaurants, a Makers Plaza for craftsmen, as well as potential office space.

title: Teens Lead Community Cleanup Along Broadway in Chula Vista
summary:
“I'm here to make Broadway beautiful, clean it up so that people get exposed to this beautiful city that I grew up in,” Youth for Change Advocate Montse Urbina told NBC 7.
Young men and women gathered on Saturday through the South Bay chapter of non-profit organization Youth for Change.
It's good for the city of Chula Vista because we can have more business in the neighborhood,” a local business owner said.
The cleanup came from a partnership with the City of Chula Vista who donated the supplies through their 'Buff-A-Block' program.
The City of Chula Vista also plans to build new bike lanes on Broadway as well as traffic signal upgrades to better adjust to real-time traffic conditions.

title: Clown Crew Wanted for Vandalizing South Bay Campuses
summary:
Chula Vista police are looking for a group of young men accused of dressing up like creepy clowns and vandalizing several South Bay schools.
Investigators said the group is wanted for vandalizing three campuses in the Sweetwater Union High School District.
Their posts show them in full clown costumes, clowning around on Montgomery High School's campus and at multiple other South Bay schools.
They should respect the schools,” parent Andrea Welch said as she picked up her daughter from an event at Hilltop High School.
And at Hilltop High School, police said the clown crew crashed a custodial golf cart.

title: Chula Vista Pays $281,000 For Sidewalk Injury
summary:
The city of Chula Vista paid $281,000 to a woman who was injured after stepping into an empty tree planter on a busy city sidewalk, according to public documents obtained by NBC 7 Investigates.
In June, the city settled a lawsuit filed by Leilani Kaloha for severe injuries she suffered during a September 2017 walk on 3rd Avenue.
Kaloha filed a lawsuit against the city, a tree maintenance company, and the local business district in January 2018.
“The city and other defendants did the right thing in compensating Ms. Kaloha,” wrote attorney Matt de Lira who represented Kaloha.
Here, Ms. Kaloha’s settlement exceeded the annual budget of the city’s Urban Forestry Department – which after this incident was reorganized.

title: Fall heat wave turns ‘happiest place on Earth’ into hottest place in America
summary:
“Ironically, no records were broken, but it was still hot,” said Jimmy Taeger, a weather service meteorologist in San Diego.
However, the mercury reached a record-breaking high of 100 degrees on the same day in 2017.

In San Bernardino, firefighters took on a blaze that broke out Monday afternoon near homes in the Little Mountain area.

title: Bank robber reportedly makes getaway on electric scooter
summary:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. (KGTV) -- The FBI and Chula Vista police are looking for a man suspected of robbing a bank in Chula Vista and making his getaway on a Lime scooter.
According to the FBI, the robbery happened Oct. 14 at the Chase bank branch on Olympic Parkway.
During the robbery, a man wearing sunglasses flashed a gun and was able to get away with an undisclosed amount of cash.
The same man is also wanted in connection with a bank robbery in early October at a US Bank on Saturn Boulevard in south San Diego.
Anyone with information is asked to call Chula Vista police at 619-691-5151.

title: Teen Learning to Drive Hits Hydrant, Causes Watery Mess in Chula Vista
summary:
Share This Article:A teenage driver with a learner’s permit hit a fire hydrant Sunday afternoon, sending water shooting into the air in Chula Vista.
Water shot into the some 40 to 50 feet and flooded down the street for about a half hour until a technician from the Otay Water District could get the line shut off.
As a result, water was also shut off to many of the surrounding homes.
In additional to the Otay Water District, crews from the Chula Vista Fire Department, as well as the Chula Vista Police Department, were at the scene working to restore service and clear the mess.

title: Driver Arrested After Allegedly Hitting Teen With Car Who Threw Food at His Mercedes-Benz: CVPD
summary:
A man was arrested Monday night after he reportedly struck a teen with his car and proceeded to punch him multiple times near a Chula Vista golf course after the teen and a friend supposedly threw food at his Mercedes-Benz, police said.
Garrett Perry, 41, faces charges of felony child endangerment, assault with a deadly weapon, and robbery, according to the Chula Vista Police Department.
On Monday, two boys, aged 14 and 15, allegedly threw food at Perry’s Mercedes-Benz at the East Lake Country Club at around 5:45 p.m.
The teens then fled on bicycles near North Greensview Drive and Masters Ridge Road, but Perry reportedly followed behind, according to CVPD.
After the collision, Perry allegedly punched the teen multiple times, according to CVPD.

title: 2019 started and ended wet in San Diego; heat was less persistent
summary:
Last year came in and went out like a wet lion in San Diego County.
While the planet as a whole experienced in 2019 what will likely go down as the hottest year on record, San Diego, for the most part, dodged persistent heat.
San Diego recorded more than 6 inches of rain during the months — more than half of the normal annual total.
AdvertisementAlso keeping the weather mild in San Diego through the middle of the year were the much cooler waters off the county coast.
“It’s been a very, very active last six weeks or so.”AdvertisementSix storms hit San Diego over that stretch.

title: San Marcos city computer systems hacked
summary:
Computer systems at the city of San Marcos were hacked last week, in an attack that has interfered with email accounts and other internal functions, but has not resulted in data breaches, city officials said.
City email accounts were disabled, and messages sent to the city were returned with the notices “Delivery Delayed: report of hack on San Marcos city systems.”AdvertisementHowever, she said, sensitive data wasn’t affected and there were no financial losses, other than the time spent addressing the problem.
She declined to say what steps the city is taking to address the hack and secure city systems.
City facilities remain open during the investigation, and emergency services are working, officials said.
“The City of San Marcos recently identified a technical issue that has affected the availability of some of our computer systems,” the city notice stated.

title: Proposition 13 treats all California property taxes the same. Voters could change that in 2020
summary:
They are likely to get that chance with the ballot measure submitted to state officials for formal review on Tuesday.
Business property values would have to be updated by county assessors at least every three years.
That voters will be asked next year to consider a so-called “split roll” change to Proposition 13 has been known for months.
Defenders and critics of Proposition 13 alike agree that some version of the “split roll” change has been discussed for years.
Supporters of the effort to revamp Proposition 13 have spent years convincing even those who share their ideology to embrace the blistering battle that lies ahead.

title: Person with measles traveled to Disneyland while infectious, officials say
summary:

in West Los Angeles before traveling to Disneyland.
The news comes about two months after a teenager from New Zealand visited Los Angeles and Orange counties and went to Disneyland in August while she was sick with measles.
AdvertisementIn 2014, California experienced a large measles outbreak after someone with measles visited Disneyland over the holidays.
There have been 19 measles cases among Los Angeles County residents in 2019, in addition to 11 non-resident measles cases that traveled through Los Angeles County — excluding Long Beach and Pasadena, as cases identified in those cities are reported by their local health departments — according to the county health department.

title: Vista outage briefly leaves 22K without power, slows traffic on SR-78
summary:
A power outage Tuesday afternoon in Vista briefly left more than 22,000 customers without electricity and affected traffic signals just off state Route 78, slowing traffic near College Boulevard and Emerald Drive ahead of rush-hour evening traffic.
“A Mylar balloon was the culprit,” San Diego Gas & Electric spokeswoman Denice Menard said.
The balloon hit a circuit breaker just before 2:30 p.m., leaving 22,186 customers without power for about 30 minutes., Menard said.
But SDG&E crews were able to quickly restore power to roughly 90 percent of the customers by about 3 p.m.Just more than 2,400 customers remained without power as of 3:45 p.m., according to Menard and an SDG&E outage map.
The electricity was restored to all customers before 5 p.m.Advertisement🚧🚔SR-78 in the area of area near Emerald and College is affected due to a power outage in the area.

title: 3-year ban on police use of facial recognition technology in California to start in the new year
summary:
Regional law enforcement agencies have used facial recognition technology for years to help them identify people who are either unwilling or unable to identify themselves.
Facial recognition obviously makes things faster and can narrow down the scope faster than traditional ways, but it’s not the end-all of identifying people.”Assembly Bill 1215 prohibits officers and deputies throughout the state from using cameras for facial recognition and biometric surveillance.
San Francisco and Oakland were among the first cities in the country to place specific bans on facial recognition technology, as was Somerville, Massachusetts.
In May, San Francisco passed its “Stop Secret Surveillance” ordinance, which banned city government agencies from using facial recognition technology.
While facial recognition has been useful in authenticating or helping to figure out a person’s identity, it has proven less effective when identifying women and people of color.

title: New COVID-19 cluster identified, cases near 300
summary:

The number of people with the disease hit 297 on Wednesday, including 277 county residents and 20 travelers held in local quarantine.
The youngest was 6 weeks old and the oldest was over 80, and two county residents have died of the disease.
