SeaWorld Entertainment announced last month that it will redevelop the Aquatica San Diego water park into the “Sesame Street”-themed park, the first such theme park on the west coast and only the second in the country.

title: 2 stabbed after man thrown out of party tries to get back inside
summary:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. — A man was arrested Saturday after allegedly stabbing two people while trying to force his way into a house party in Chula Vista, authorities said.
Police said a man who had been kicked out of a party was trying to make his way back inside when a woman and another man stopped him.
The man then stabbed both people and ran away, according to authorities.
The female victim was taken to a hospital for treatment of her injuries and was in stable condition, police said.
The male stabbing victim took himself to a hospital and was also in stable condition.

title: Fire Rips Through Commercial Building Under Construction in Chula Vista
summary:
Firefighters managed to extinguish a fire at commercial building in Chula Vista, Sunday.
It turns out the Chula Vista Fire Department had been at this location a couple days ago extinguishing another fire in the same building.
“We had a commercial structure fire that had previously burned possibly a couple months ago,” said CVFD Battalion Chief Brendan Barahura.
“And we had another fire here two days ago.”CVFD managed to arrive at the scene quickly and contained the fire to one side of the building.
Firefighter investigators are looking into the cause as there appears to be homeless encampments behind the building.

title: Storm drops 2 inches of rain in San Diego County, with more on the way
summary:
The precipitation was concentrated in the area from the coast to the mountains in northern San Diego County.
AdvertisementForecasters say that a cold storm in the north is pulling the tropical moisture into the San Diego area.
It appears that San Diego will end up with 1.5 to 2 inches of rain, while spots like Julian get 2 inches to 3 inches, and possibly 3 to 4 inches at Mt.
A flash flood watch will be in effect across San Diego County until early Thursday.
General Dynamics-NASSCO has canceled the first shift on Wednesday at its San Diego shipyard.

title: Little Caesar’s Franchisee Withholding Paychecks: Lawsuit
summary:
On the eve of Thanksgiving, employees at several San Diego-area Little Caesar's Pizza franchises claim they're not getting paid.
It’s all part of a much larger fight between Yaroun “Tony” Bith, owner of several San Diego County franchises, and the Little Caesar’s corporate office that's now trying to shut him down.
The lights are off and a sign on the Little Caesar's door in Barrio Logan reads: "Temporarily closed for maintenance."
“It’s my favorite pizza,” said Armando Gonzalez Jr.Gonzalez’s father isn’t happy to hear how Bith has allegedly been treating his employees.
Little Caesar's corporate office filed a complaint against him in July, claiming at least 10 checks he sent them from September 2018 to April 2019, totaling more than $160,000, have been returned for insufficient funds.

title: Brush Fire Briefly Threatens Homes In Chula Vista
summary:
CHULA VISTA, CA — A brush fire that broke out Wednesday night briefly threatened a mobile home park in Chula Vista.
The blaze broke out before 10:20 p.m. and burned toward the La Palma Mobile Estates on Palm Avenue, Fox 5 reported.
NBC 7 reported that the Chula Vista Fire Department issued evacuation orders in the area.
The blaze broke out not long after crews stopped a brush fire that sparked off northbound Interstate 805 in Chula Vista.
The fire also sparked amid a red flag warning that wasn't set to expire until 6 p.m. Thursday.

title: Shot fired in fight outside Chula Vista hotel; woman, teen arrested
summary:
Gunfire outside a Chula Vista hotel on Saturday night put an end to a fight between two groups of registered guests, but no one was injured, police said.
Officers arrested a woman suspected as the shooter and a 17-year-old boy caught with a concealed, loaded gun, police Lt. Rusty Rea said.
Rea said it wasn’t clear what touched off the fight between guests in different rooms at the Rodeway Inn & Suites on Broadway about 9 p.m.
Some of the combatants were gone by the time police got there, but officers later detained, then arrested a woman on suspicion with a deadly weapon.
Rea said her gun was not found, but a handgun was found on the teenager who had been on the opposite side of the fight.

title: Legal meets illegal as Vista’s first licensed marijuana dispensaries open for business
summary:
Though it is now legal to sell marijuana in Vista, that does not necessarily mean the illegal route has gone away.
On a recent weekday morning, customers trickled into the city’s first two licensed medical marijuana storefronts, while, just down the street, an unlicensed and illegal shop continued to flourish, sometimes drawing enough vehicles to require overflow parking.
AdvertisementThis is a the store front of an illegal marijuana dispensary at 1562 South Santa Fe Avenue on November 6, 2019 in Vista, California.
But the current connection between Tradecraft and the illegal shop on South Santa Fe is unclear.
Legally, it really doesn’t matter whether or not the owner of a licensed shop previously operated an illegal storefront.

title: Trial testimony wraps up in killing of Chula Vista man found in oil drum in San Diego Bay
summary:
Testimony wrapped up Wednesday in the trial of two men accused in the stabbing death of a Chula Vista music producer whose body was found in a drum floating in San Diego Bay.
Timothy John Cook, 54, is charged with murder in the Sept. 30, 2017 killing of his 28-year-old housemate, Omar Medina.
AdvertisementMedina’s family never heard from him after Sept. 30, and filed a missing person’s report soon afterward with Chula Vista police.
The attorney said the prosecution lacked a murder weapon and witnesses to the killing, which allegedly occurred during the daytime hours of Sept. 30 at the Chula Vista home.
The prosecutor alleged that a barrel matching the one containing Medina’s body can be seen in the bed of the pickup.

title: Fire burns homeless encampment near Chula Vista riverbed
summary:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. (KGTV) -- A man was detained after he was seen fleeing from a fire that burned at a homeless encampment in Chula Vista early Tuesday morning.
The fire was reported at around 3 a.m. in an area near Faivre and Jacqua streets, according to authorities.
10News learned the man told police there were other people in the riverbed below as the fire raged.
It is unknown if the man detained was arrested.
The fire ignited in the same area where a similar blaze erupted during Red Flag conditions several weeks ago.

title: Man arrested on suspicion of stabbing his son at Vista home -
summary:
Man arrested on suspicion of stabbing his son at Vista homeVISTA (KUSI) – A 60-year-old man was behind bars Friday on suspicion of stabbing his 23-year-old son at a Vista home, authorities said.
Dispatchers received a call around 8:15 p.m. Thursday from a person who reported the stabbing in the 1500 block of South Melrose Drive, San Diego County Sheriff’s Lt. Cliff Rinder said.
Deputies responded to the scene, found the son suffering from multiple stab wounds and arrested the father, Rinder said.
The son was taken to Tri-City Medical Center in Oceanside for treatment of his injuries, which were not believed to be life-threatening, the lieutenant said.
The father, identified as 60-year-old Paul Voytko, was booked into the Vista Detention Facility on suspicion of assault with a deadly weapon, according to jail records.

title: Chula Vista City Council incumbents at top in primary as attention shifts toward November
summary:
Incumbents running for Chula Vista City Council had strong showings in the primary elections as results showed both Stephen Padilla and Mike Diaz out in front in their district races.
AdvertisementIf the results hold up, Padilla will face Martinez and Diaz will square off against Cardenas in November.
Unofficial results showed local businessman Doug Wolf third in the District 4 race with 1,143 votes and union organizer Delfina Gonzalez finishing last in the District 3 race with 905 votes.
Padilla has decades of political experience including serving as mayor of Chula Vista while also serving in the Port of San Diego and Coastal Commission.
In his first term, Diaz brought resources to his southwest Chula Vista district and helped pave 8 miles of roads and resurface 1,200 feet of sidewalks in his district.

summary:

Expect more shops in Vista soon — the citizen's initiative allows for up to 11.

title: Sears in Chula Vista Closing as Company Shutters 96 Locations Nationwide
summary:
Share This Article:A Sears in Chula Vista is one of nine Sears and Kmart outlets that will be closing in December as the company’s new owners continue efforts to streamline the struggling legacy retail chain.
Support Times of San Diego's growthwith a small monthly contribution Become a supporterTransform Holdco LLC, which purchased all assets of Sears Holdings Corp. in February, announced Thursday it will be shuttering 96 locations across the country.
In addition to the Sears at 565 Broadway in Chula Vista, other stores closing are in Baldwin Hills, North Hollywood, West Covina, Temecula, Riverside, Moreno Valley and Palm Desert.
The only Kmart closing is in Riverside.

title: Victim carjacked, kidnapped by men disguised as officers
summary:
× Victim carjacked, kidnapped by men disguised as officersCHULA VISTA, Calif. — Chula Vista police are investigating a carjacking and kidnapping involving perpetrators disguised as law enforcement, according to KGTV.
The incident was reported just before midnight Tuesday, Nov. 19 in the Rancho Del Rey III neighborhood in East Chula Vista.
The men released the victim at the park, according to police.
Chula Vista police said that while the men were dressed to appear like officers, they were not wearing police insignia.
Anyone with information about this incident was urged to call Chula Vista Police Department.

title: Chula Vista will ask voters to decide whether to repeal measure against project labor agreements
summary:
The city of Chula Vista will ask voters to decide in March 2020 whether to repeal a 2010 measure that bans contracts that require labor agreements on city projects.
G prohibits the city from agreeing to contracts that require: collective bargaining agreements, payments into union trust funds or the use of union workers — matters usually addressed within project labor agreements.
Jerry Brown signed into law two bills, Senate Bill 922 and Senate Bill 829, that aimed to keep funding from cities with policies against project labor agreements.
The laws did not apply to cities that enacted policies against project labor agreements before November 2011 until January 2015.
“I don’t want to see it stop,” he said, adding that the city needs state funding to complete projects.

title: Coronavirus: AT&T Store Employee In Chula Vista Tests Positive
summary:
CHULA VISTA, CA — A Chula Vista AT&T store employee who lives in Orange County has tested positive for the new coronavirus.
"The city of Chula Vista is providing this information out of an abundance of caution," city officials said in a statement.
The affected stores were in Chula Vista, Escondido, San Marcos, Oceanside, National City and Vista, he said.

title: California Could See Storm Damages Costing A Billion Dollars Each Year
summary:
Newly published research from the Scripps Institution of Oceanography finds certain storm systems have the potential to cause severe flooding damage in California.
The study, published Wednesday in the journal Scientific Advances, predicts the state could endure flooding that causes a billion dollars worth of damage each year.
The weather phenomenon known as atmospheric rivers can be beneficial if it is mild, like the one that passed through San Diego this week.
“Recent research indicates that atmospheric rivers are getting longer wider and wetter as the century progresses due to human-caused global warming and climate change,” Corringham said.
That includes climate change, endangered species, habitat, urbanization, pollution and many other topics.

title: Year in Review: Top San Diego news stories of 2019
summary:
SAN DIEGO — With the new year quickly approaching, here’s a look back at some of our top stories from 2019.
February 18: Crews rescued 16 people after a ride at SeaWorld San Diego malfunctioned.
March 12: Dozens of San Diego parents were indicted for their alleged involvement in a nationwide college admission scandal.
The investigation — which continued throughout 2019 — involved alumni and aspiring student athletes at University of San Diego, UCLA, USC and several other prominent universities across the country.
June 28: A 2-year-old boy died following an E. coli infection linked to animals at the San Diego County Fair.

title: Blood Needed This Flu Season: Donate Blood In San Diego County
summary:
SAN DIEGO — It's flu season.
As flu activity picks up this fall, the American Red Cross is asking healthy people of all blood types to give blood or platelets to ensure a strong blood supply for patients in need in San Diego County.
There are many opportunities for people to donate blood or platelets in the county.
Upcoming blood drives in San Diego CountyCarlsbad11/10/2019: 8 a.m. - 2 p.m., New Song Community Church, 3780 Pio Pico Drive11/11/2019: 8 a.m. - 2 p.m., Army and Navy Academy, 2605 Carlsbad Blvd.

title: New San Diego regional energy program picks a name
summary:
The San Diego region’s new kid on the energy block now has a name.
AdvertisementThe winning name beat out four other suggestions — America’s Finest Energy, Empower SD, Amiga(s) Community Energy and Southern California Community Power.
but California CCAs promote their ability to provide customers energy from more renewable sources at rates equal to or lower than traditional utilities.
When the city of San Diego unveiled its business plan last year, its consultant estimated startup costs of $103 million.
SDCP will become the second CCA in San Diego County, joining Solana Beach that launched its own stand-alone program last year.

title: Chula Vista’s Miren Algorri Named by Newsom to Early Childhood Policy Panel
summary:
Gavin Newsom announced the appointment Friday of a Chula Vista woman to a subcommittee of the newly formed Early Childhood Policy Council.
Child care provider and Chula Vista resident Miren Algorri, 45, will serve on the Workforce Subcommittee following Newsom’s appointment.
Algorri has been a child-care provider with Algorri Family Childcare since 1996, according to the governor’s office.
The council will advise state officials on how to craft policy for early childhood learning and care and how to improve the state’s forthcoming Master Plan for Early Learning and Care and a final report from the Assembly’s Blue Ribbon Commission on Early Childhood Education.
“Every child in our state should have the resources and support they need to live happy and healthy lives,” Newsom said.

title: Water Flows Again Through Pipeline From Temecula to Chula Vista After Repairs to Crack
summary:
A pipeline that spans almost the entire length of San Diego County is back in use after engineers spent weeks patching a massive crack in the pipe's infrastructure.
The San Diego County Water Authority (SDCWA) discovered a leak in September to a portion of its 90-inch Pipeline 4, which has carried water since 1966 from the Skinner Water Treatment Plant near Temecula down to the Otay Reservoir near Chula Vista.
NBC 7 was the only news media outlet invited inside the pipe in September before repairs began.
Engineers spent weeks 20 feet underground near Bonsall using a wallpaper-like carbon fiber to line the split.
Before repairs, water from outside the pipe was seeping inside.

title: Blood Needed This Flu Season: Donate Blood In Escondido
summary:
As flu activity picks up this fall, the American Red Cross is asking healthy people of all blood types to give blood or platelets to ensure a strong blood supply for patients in need in San Diego County.
There is no waiting period to give blood or platelets after receiving a flu shot as long as the donor is fever- and symptom-free, according to the Red Cross.
There are many opportunities for people to donate blood or platelets in the county.
Download the American Red Cross Blood Donor App, visit redcrossblood.org or call 1-800-RED CROSS (1-800-733-2767) for more information or to make an appointment.
A blood donor card or driver's license or two other forms of identification are required at check-in.

title: NBC 7 & Telemundo 20 Providing Help For the Hungry
summary:
NBC 7 with sister station NBC 4 in Los Angeles is bringing back the award-winning Help 4 the Hungry food donation drive, launching Nov. 22 through Dec. 24 to raise awareness about hunger and homelessness in Southern California.
The stations have teamed up with Ralphs and Food 4 Less supermarkets to offer the public a convenient way to donate $5 or $10 at checkout with 100 percent of proceeds in San Diego benifiting Feeding San Diego.
Other regional food banks in Orange, Riverside, San Bernardino, Los Angeles and Ventura counties will also be benifiting from Help 4 the Hungry.
Last year's inaugural campaign raised more than $400,000 distributed to the regional food banks, providing more than 1.5 million meals to those in need.
This year, NBC 7 joins the effort to expand the assistance to more people, additional food banks and provide millions of meals throughout the region.

title: How This Winter Compares to Typical Winters in Your City – 24
summary:
How This Winter Compares to Typical Winters in Your City Thomas C. FrohlichJanuary 2020 was the world’s warmest January on record, according to scientists at NOAA’s National Centers for Environmental Information, which maintains a 141 year climate history.
But while globally this January was the warmest, not all places have experienced similarly mild winter weather this year.
The average temperature this winter through January was lower than the respective historical averages in just 15 of 1,218 U.S. weather stations.
Some of these weather stations lie within the municipal boundaries of the major city with which they are associated.

title: 63-year-old man struck crossing Vista street, later dies
summary:
A 63-year-old man was struck by a vehicle on Vista street early Tuesday morning, and later died, a sheriff’s sergeant said.
The man was crossing East Vista Way near Townsite Drive about 5:45 a.m. when he was struck by a vehicle headed north, Sgt.
The victim was taken to a hospital, where he later died.
Alcohol does not appear to have been a factor in the incident, Gonzalez said.
AdvertisementThe northbound lanes of East Vista Way in the area were closed during the investigation.

title: Chula Vista adds more fees to open a marijuana business
summary:
Opening a marijuana business in Chula Vista just got more expensive.
The City Council recently approved five new application and regulatory fees, raising the costs to open a cannabis business from about $7,000 to at least $55,000.
AdvertisementThe city of Vista charges marijuana businesses more up front.
Chula Vista, which could become home to the largest marijuana market in San Diego County, is currently evaluating business license applications and has yet to issue any licenses.
In the first phase of the application process, applicants must show they have at least $250,000 in liquid assets.

title: 5 dead, including 3 children, in domestic violence murder-suicide in Paradise Hills
summary:
When an emergency dispatcher answered the first 911 phone call from a home in Paradise Hills Saturday morning, nobody was on the other end of the line.
Advertisement“It appears to be a tragic case of domestic violence murder-suicide,” homicide Lt. Matt Dobbs said a news conference Saturday afternoon.
A San Diego Police officer stands at the scene of a shooting in Paradise Hills on Saturday.
AdvertisementAccording to the San Diego Domestic Violence Council, 17,513 incidents were reported in San Diego County in 2018, up 4 percent from the previous year.
“The tragedy today in Paradise Hills is terribly sad,” Mayor Kevin Faulconer said via Twitter.

title: Chula Vista’s Otay Ranch among the top-selling developments last year
summary:
If it feels busier in Otay Ranch, there’s a reason for that.
The large Otay Ranch development, close to the U.S.-Mexico border, is 25,000 acres and nearly the size of San Francisco.
Otay Ranch has made the list several times over the years, but this is its highest ranking.
However, Otay Ranch is dense with small lots and numerous apartment buildings and townhouses — not exactly the quiet suburban area that people looking to live outside the city might expect.
The area now known as Otay Ranch had been used as ranchland for cattle since the 19th century.

title: Chula Vista Police Raid Illegal Marijuana Dispensary, Seize $5-10 million in Cannabis
summary:
Share This Article:Police Friday raided an illegal South Bay marijuana dispensary and made six arrests.
A half-dozen people were taken into custody on suspicion of possession of marijuana for sales, conspiracy to sale marijuana and operating a marijuana dispensary without a license, according to a police statement.
No dispensaries have been legally permitted in Chula Vista, where police raided another illegal marijuana dispensary on Sept. 20 in the 700 block of Third Avenue, seizing its stock and arresting its staff.
Since the start of the year, the Chula Vista Police Department and City Attorney’s Office have closed more than a dozen illegally operated marijuana dispensaries.

title: Flu Deaths Of 2019-20 Season Begin In California
summary:
BAY AREA, CA — Two Santa Clara County residents, including a child, have died recently from the flu, county officials said Tuesday.
County public health officials do not know if either person received the flu vaccine, but said the deaths serve as a reminder of the importance of getting the flu vaccine.
The case is that county's first pediatric flu-related death of the 2019-2020 flu season, according to officials.
The man, whose name was withheld, also had additional medical issues, according to county health officials.
It was the county's first influenza death for the 2019-20 season.

title: Franchisees File Claim Against Donut Bar After Abrupt Closures
summary:
One week after the Donut Bar franchise in Chula Vista abruptly closed its doors, the franchisee, joined by two other franchise owners, filed a claim against the Donut Bar brand, saying they were misled about operating costs.
Franchise attorney David Levaton represented the owners of three Donut Bar locations in Chula Vista, Oceanside, and Scottsdale, Arizona.
Elizabeth Slaven and Thierry Dewaghe ran the Chula Vista franchise, which shuttered on Nov. 4.
Levaton claimed the Donut Bar did not disclose certain information about bankruptcies and litigation against the company, and gave franchisees like Slaven and Dewaghe misleading information about start-up business costs.
"Donut Bar opened in Eastlake by popular demand and has enjoyed overwhelming success, support and praise," Campa said via email.

title: 1 Stabbed, 1 Injured In Attack Near Chula Vista Intersection
summary:
CHULA VISTA, CA — One man was stabbed in the abdomen and another man suffered a minor laceration Wednesday morning when they were attacked by two groups of men from two separate cars after getting into an argument near a Chula Vista intersection, police said.
The altercation happened around 2 a.m. near Broadway and Flower Street, Chula Vista Police Lt. Scott Adkins said.
The two victims were walking northbound on Broadway when they got into an argument for unknown reasons with a motorist in a car near the intersection, Adkins said.
A fight ensued, during which one of the victims was stabbed in the lower abdomen and the other victim suffered a laceration to his abdomen, the lieutenant said.
No description of the suspects was immediately available, but the two cars were described as Volkswagen Jettas, one silver and one black.

title: 3 children struck by car, injured, in Chula Vista
summary:
Three children were struck by a car as they were crossing a road in Chula Vista Saturday afternoon.
Two of the children, ages 2 and 4, were treated for minor injuries but a 15-year-old suffered a head injury, scrapes and cuts, according to Chula Vista police.
The children were not using a crosswalk as they headed across Santa Victoria Road, near Santa Alexia Avenue, police said.
The driver stopped right away and several people called 911 shortly before 4 p.m. to report the collision.
AdvertisementPolice said the driver was cooperative with officers and was not believed to be impaired by drugs or alcohol.

title: 2019 started and ended wet in San Diego; heat was less persistent
summary:
Last year came in and went out like a wet lion in San Diego County.
While the planet as a whole experienced in 2019 what will likely go down as the hottest year on record, San Diego, for the most part, dodged persistent heat.
San Diego recorded more than 6 inches of rain during the months — more than half of the normal annual total.
AdvertisementAlso keeping the weather mild in San Diego through the middle of the year were the much cooler waters off the county coast.
“It’s been a very, very active last six weeks or so.”AdvertisementSix storms hit San Diego over that stretch.

title: Controversy Over $42,000 in Security Costs for Chula Vista Drag Queen Happy Hour
summary:
Opponents of a Chula Vista library’s “Drag Queen Storytime” said they were outraged over the nearly $42,000 paid to Chula Vista Police Department to manage protesters at the September event.
The event at Chula Vista Central Library featured two drag queens reading children’s books to kids and their families.
Hundreds of protestors for and against a ‘Drag Queen Story Time’ lined the streets outside of a Chula Vista public library.
Protestors & supporters of Drag Queen Story Time clashed outside the Chula Vista Library as drag queens Barbie Q & Raquelita read to children.
The highly protested and much anticipated "Drag Queen Story Time" event finally kicked off today at the Chula Vista Public Library.

title: Fire threatens homes in Chula Vista
summary:
This is an archived article and the information in the article may be outdated.
Please enable Javascript to watch this videoCHULA VISTA, Calif. -- A brush fire burned near homes in Chula Vista Friday evening.
The blaze was reported near the 400 block of Agua Vista Drive near the Bella Lago neighborhood.
Chula Vista Fire had help from multiple departments totaling 25 engines, 120 fire fighters and five aircrafts to get the fire out quickly before any serious damage could be done.
The fire was fairly close to homes, but crews were more than prepared with their attack even though the “red flag warning“ had just expired.

summary:
SAN DIEGO — Editor’s note: This story shows updates about the coronavirus outbreak in San Diego, CA from March 15-21, 2020.

title: Chula Vista woman becomes city’s first immigrant affairs manager
summary:
SAN DIEGO — San Diego Wednesday welcomed its first immigrant affairs manager, who is tasked with overseeing the successful integration of immigrants and refugees into the city.
The city recruited Chula Vista native Rita Fernandez from Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti’s Immigrant Affairs Office, where she served as an associate director, to run San Diego’s own office.
San Diego Mayor Kevin Faulconer and City Councilwoman Georgette Gomez touted her experience and argued she will be pivotal in making the city more welcoming to immigrants.
“As a native of San Diego County and daughter of immigrants myself, I know this will be a humbling opportunity to support the region’s immigrant population,” Fernandez said.
“In the coming weeks, I look forward to speaking with community leaders and stakeholders about laying the groundwork for immigrant integration work in San Diego.”

title: Train service disrupted following bluff collapses in Del Mar
summary:
Portions of the train tracks that regularly carry passengers between Los Angeles and San Diego are closed Saturday to repair damage from a bluff collapse in Del Mar.
The repairs are taking place south of the Solana Beach train station, according to the North County Transit District.

Regularly scheduled train service for both Amtrak and the Coaster is expected to resume on Sunday.

title: High school football team loses title game 1 year after fire
summary:
A Northern California high school football team has lost in a championship game one year after a deadly fire destroyed most of their town, including the homes of most players and coaches.
Paradise High School lost to Sutter Union High School 20-7 on Saturday night in the Northern Section Division III championship game.
The high school has a football tradition, consistently fielding competitive teams.
They now live in Paradise with some friends so they can attend their old high school and play football.
Paradise High School finished the regular season undefeated, outscoring their opponents by a combined score of 469-73.

title: Chula Vista City Council OKs pay raises for itself and city attorney
summary:
The Chula Vista City Council on Tuesday approved salary increases for itself and the city attorney.
AdvertisementThe salaries of the City Council and city attorney were last increased in 2015.
Consideration of the pay raises for the City Council and city attorney followed a presentation by the city’s Charter Review Commission, which surveyed residents on a series of charter-related topics, including the City Council’s pay.
Patricia Aguilar, a former councilwoman who termed out last November, said she believes the City Council is paid too much.
She suggested that holding off on pay raises would incentivize the City Council to “fix” the city’s budget, which faces a growing deficit.

It was burning at Old Highway 80 and Tierra Del Sol Road near the Golden Acorn Casino Saturday, close to the U.S.-Mexico Border.

title: Federal grand jury in Buffalo indicts California man on drug charges
summary:
A California man has been indicted by a federal grand jury in Buffalo on charges of conspiracy to possess with intent to distribute five kilograms or more of cocaine and one kilogram or more of heroin, according to the U.S. Attorney's Office.
Prosecutors said 55-year-old David Katz, of Chula Vista, was additionally charged with attempted possession with intent to distribute one kilogram or more of heroin and attempted possession with intent to distribute five kilograms or more of cocaine.
On June 7, 2017, federal agents seized two kilograms of heroin in Phoenix and 10 kilograms of cocaine in Buffalo.
Authorities alleged Katz funded a portion of the heroin and drove it from California to Phoenix, prosecutors said.
He is detained in California and will be brought to New York at a later date.

title: Governor takes office in Baja California
summary:
Focusing heavily on the legacy of the state and the need to improve public services, Baja California Governor Jaime Bonilla spoke in Tijuana for the first time as governor at the city’s cultural center on Friday evening after taking office Nov. 1.
Baja California has long been a stronghold of the PAN, but the former administration was tarnished by allegations of corruption and persistent waves of violence in Tijuana.
José Luis Ovando Patrón, president of the state steering committee for the PAN in Baja California, responded that his political party has left Baja California as the best state to live in.
In June, Bonilla was elected governor of Baja California with a 27-point margin ahead of his closest opponent.
Critics said the Baja California legislature set a dangerous precedent that representatives could extend or reduce term lengths based on whether or not the election results were favorable to them.

title: Home price reductions down in San Diego
summary:
At the start of this year, San Diego had the second-most price reductions in the nation.
Of the nation’s 20 largest metro areas, San Diego had the ninth most price reductions in September.
AdvertisementZillow economist Jeff Tucker said the San Diego market has mellowed after a jump in price reductions — much like other high-priced markets — to the middle of the pack.
“The story with San Diego was reality setting in after prices had been rising unsustainably fast,” he said.
The median home price in San Diego County in September was $570,000, said CoreLogic data provided by DQNews, down from $575,000 at the same time last year.

title: 2019 Year in Review: San Diego's top stories
summary:
SAN DIEGO — As the decade comes to a close, we look back at some of San Diego's biggest stories in 2019.
One employee was fatally injured and two others were injured on November 6, 2019, during a shooting at Otay Mesa’s Church’s Chicken.
The San Diego man - believed to be a regular customer - opened fire after a Church’s Chicken employee refused to accept the counterfeit bill he was trying to use as payment.
Rep. Duncan Hunter pleaded guilty before a federal judge in San Diego on December 3, 2019 to misusing $150,000 in campaign funds for his own personal expenses.
While there were certainly more stories that could have made the list in 2019, these were some of the big events that happened in San Diego over the past year.

Tuesday’s high in San Diego will only reach 69 — a 22 degrees below Monday’s high.
AdvertisementA flash flood watch will go into effect in San Diego County on Tuesday night and last until early Friday.
San Diego could receive from 0.50 inches to 1.00 inch of rain during that period, while areas like Alpine, Ramona and Palomar get 1.50 inches, the weather service says.
“The rain could be heavy at times if the system from the north pulls the warm moisture from the south into San Diego,” said Joe Dandrea, a weather service forecaster.

title: California says San Diego County could undermine state’s landmark plan to rein in greenhouse gases
summary:
The stakes are rising in a legal battle over whether San Diego County will be able to approve thousands of new housing units in wildfire-prone areas far from urban job centers using carbon offsets.
AdvertisementLawyers for the county rejected the idea that the plan would put California’s climate plan in jeopardy, saying in an email to the Union-Tribune: “Our plan will help meet state targets.” County counsel declined to elaborate on the claim.
Carbon offsets can be bought through online storefronts known as registries that fund everything from land conservation to sustainable agricultural and logging practices.
Fletcher, who also sits on the state’s influential California Air Resources Board, the agency largely responsible for designing the state’s climate plan, declined an interview for this story, citing the on-going litigation.
AdvertisementHowever, the state does not recognize carbon offsets when calculating its own carbon footprint.

Emerging as top-scoring dispensaries and delivery companies were Grasshopper Cannabis Delivery, Chula Vista Cannabis, March and Ash Nirvana and Element 7 Chula Vista.
Other top-scoring businesses include UL Chula Two, Vista Property Holding, Southern Erudite Ventures and Harvest Chula Vista.
Now underway is a second round of background checks, led by the Chula Vista Police Department.
The marijuana market in Chula Vista, the second-largest city in the county, could become the largest in the region.

Chula Vista Police Department responded to reports of a carjacking around midnight on Tuesday night near East J Street and Bolero Drive, near Southwestern College.
Two suspects approached the victim wearing what he described as vests with the word “police” across the front and told him to exit his vehicle, a police report said.
The suspects ordered the victim around as if they were police, but never announced themselves as such, Peak added.

CalMatters says this living arrangement is common in New York, Massachusetts and New Jersey where cost of living is also high.
Lara says it’s where his parents live that can be the inconvenience.
While living with parents may appear on-trend, researchers says there’s not enough data to show if it’s the new norm.

title: Dozens of social-distancing violators cited in San Diego area over the weekend
summary:
SAN DIEGO COUNTY, Calif. —Dozens of San Diego-area residents and some local businesses received citations over the weekend for violating government social- distancing requirements designed to slow the spread of the deadly COVID-19 pandemic, authorities reported Monday.
In the city of San Diego, police handed out 16 tickets to individuals on Saturday and Sunday -- five in Balboa Park and 11 in the Ocean Beach area, including Sunset Cliffs and Robb Field park, SDPD public-affairs Lt. Shawn Takeuchi said.
The Chula Vista Police Department ticketed no social-distancing violators on Saturday or Sunday, CVPD Lt. Gino Grippo said.
The County of San Diego has made face coverings mandatory for those working with the public including grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations, convenience stores, and similar businesses.
While officials say these face coverings are not a substitute for practices like social distancing and handwashing, there is evidence to suggest that the use of cloth face coverings by the public during a pandemic could help reduce disease transmission.

Chula Vista officials raised the city's new Welcoming City flag to celebrate the designation and the city's immigrant community.
"It is an honor to be the first in California to be designated a Certified Welcoming City."
In its 2019 list of cities that integrate immigrants well, the New American Economy coalition ranked Chula Vista as the second-best city in the country for immigrants behind Chicago.

summary:
CHULA VISTA, Calif. (KGTV) — Surveillance video caught the moment a driver caused a fiery chain-reaction crash in a South Bay neighborhood.
Chula Vista Police said five cars were involved in the crash at East Paisley Street and Monserate Avenue just after 6 p.m. Thursday.
The crash started when a black truck hit a car, sending that vehicle into a parked car.
The suspect of the black truck kept driving, hitting another car parked in a driveway that was being worked on by two people, knocking them unconscious.
Chula Vista Police said they were investigating if alcohol or drugs were a factor in the incident.

The 33-year-old man, whose name was not immediately released, was taken to a hospital for treatment of his injuries, which were not believed to be life-threatening, Adkins said.

title: Man shot at front door of a Chula Vista home
summary:

The shooting was reported just before 12:45 a.m. Friday in the 1000 block of Barrett Avenue, according to Chula Vista police.
Some residents who went outside to see what happened found the 33-year-old man lying in front of a door with multiple gunshot wounds.
A woman who lives in the home said the man does not live there and had run to the house to hide.

title: Year in Review: Top San Diego news stories of 2019
summary:
SAN DIEGO — With the new year quickly approaching, here’s a look back at some of our top stories from 2019.
February 18: Crews rescued 16 people after a ride at SeaWorld San Diego malfunctioned.

title: Chula Vista councilmember Steve Padilla voted as California Coastal Commission chair -
summary:
Chula Vista councilmember Steve Padilla voted as California Coastal Commission chairSAN DIEGO (KUSI) – Steve Padilla is the first openly LGBT chair of the California Coastal Commission and the first from San Diego County in decades.
Newly elected Steve Padilla stopped by Good Morning San Diego to speak on important climate issues he is determined to tackle throughout the state as well as locally.
Padilla’s priorities include addressing the effects of climate change and sea-level rise, expanding public access to the coast and putting a spotlight on environmental justice for polluted and low-income communities.
In San Diego County, Padilla hopes to address the Del Mar Bluffs, the safe decommissioning of the San Onofre Nuclear Power Plant and working with regional leaders to combat the toxic sewage of the Tijuana River.
To learn more about Steve Padilla and his efforts, visit www.ChulaVistaCA.gov.

summary:
But the weather across San Diego County will be mostly dry until early next week, when a trough might bring rain on or about Christmas Eve, according to the National Weather Service.
Forecasters thought that light rain might flow ashore in the middle of this week.
But the latest models show that a system from the north has weakened and won’t make it this far south.
Instead, San Diego will start the week with temperatures in the upper 60s, about 2 to 3 degrees above average.

summary:

Police said the shooting occurred after a 20-year-old man placed an advertisement on social media to sell marijuana and a 19-year-old woman and an 18-year-old man responded to the ad.
The two got into the seller’s car, with the woman getting into the front seat and the man getting in the back seat on Biola Avenue near Alosta Street.

title: Woman, 18, shot in Nestor botched drug deal dies; boy, 16, charged with homicide
summary:
An 18-year-old woman who was shot earlier this month during a botched drug deal in Nestor died last week, and authorities have arrested and charged a 16-year-old boy in connection with the homicide, San Diego police said Tuesday.
Richella Funiestas of San Diego was shot around 7:45 p.m. on Saturday, Dec. 21, during a drug deal gone wrong inside a car on Biola Avenue near Alosta Street, according to San Diego police Officer Robert Heims and homicide Lt. Matt Dobbs.
Funiestas got into the front seat of the car with the seller, while the other person got in the back seat, police said.
As the person in the back seat was pistol-whipping the driver, the gun fired twice and Funiestas was shot in the shoulder.
AdvertisementSan Diego police and the county District Attorney’s Office are continuing to investigate Funiestas’ homicide, and anyone with information was asked to call the police homicide unit at (619) 531-2293, or San Diego County Crime Stoppers at (888) 580-8477.

title: Small airplane makes hard landing on south I-5 in Carlsbad; pilot and passenger uninjured
summary:
A small, single-engine Cessna made an emergency landing Thursday night on Interstate 5 in Carlsbad, but the two people on board walked away uninjured, authorities said.
The plane lost power and made a hard landing about 7:10 p.m. in the southbound lanes of the freeway near Tamarack Avenue, Carlsbad fire Division Chief Mike Lopez said.
The 58-year-old Covina pilot put the plane down near the median, and both he and his 58-year-old passenger were uninjured.
Authorities shut down all southbound lanes of the freeway in the area for about 30 minutes.
AdvertisementThe non-injury freeway landing was at least the second of its kind in San Diego County in the past 15 months.

title: Rain storm likely to miss San Diego -
summary:
Weather 12/30/19 – Rain storm likely to miss San DiegoSAN DIEGO (KUSI) – A storm that was headed toward the San Diego area is weakening as it moves south from the Central California coast and now is forecast to bring little, if any, rain Monday, KUSI’s Francella Perez said Monday.
The forecast now calls for partly to mostly cloudy skies Monday, with a 20-percent chance of about a 10th of an inch of rain or less, and winter weather advisories have been canceled.
Temperatures Monday will be in the low 60s, with more sunny conditions starting Tuesday.
Tuesday’s highs in San Diego will be in the upper 60s and could hit 70 by the weekend.
High surf is predicted for beaches late in the week, with crests of eight to 10 feet is likely along parts of the San Diego coast, KUSI Meteorologist Francella Perez reports.

title: SENTRE Acquires Chula Vista Retail Center for $31M
summary:
December 11, 2019 Comments Off on SENTRE Acquires Chula Vista Retail Center for $31M Views: 752 California News, San DiegoSan Diego-based SENTRE has acquired Bonita Point Plaza in Chula Vista, CA for $30.65 million.
The 58,761-square-foot shopping center features 27 tenants including Rite Aid, Starbucks, Chipotle, Wells Fargo, Chase Bank and Navy Federal Credit Union.
SENTRE acquired the property from Sudberry Properties and was represented by Steve Avoyer and Brad Williams of Flocke & Avoyer Commercial Real Estate and John Still of Point Realty Advisors.
Located at the intersection of 1451-1479 East H St. and 720-752 Otay Lakes Rd., the center enjoys solid fundamentals including 30,000 vehicle trips each day and Southwestern College’s 19,500 students.

title: Shot fired in fight outside Chula Vista hotel; woman, teen arrested
summary:
Gunfire outside a Chula Vista hotel on Saturday night put an end to a fight between two groups of registered guests, but no one was injured, police said.
Officers arrested a woman suspected as the shooter and a 17-year-old boy caught with a concealed, loaded gun, police Lt. Rusty Rea said.
Rea said it wasn’t clear what touched off the fight between guests in different rooms at the Rodeway Inn & Suites on Broadway about 9 p.m.
Some of the combatants were gone by the time police got there, but officers later detained, then arrested a woman on suspicion with a deadly weapon.
Rea said her gun was not found, but a handgun was found on the teenager who had been on the opposite side of the fight.

title: San Diego median home price hits all-time high of $594K
summary:
San Diego County’s median home price hit an all-time high of $594,455, pushed up by declining inventory and dropping interest rates.
In November, there were 5,541 homes for sale, said the Greater San Diego Association of Realtors, down from 7,445 at the same time last year.

title: 2nd Holiday Storm Drenches San Diego, Brings Inches of Snow
summary:
San Diego County was doused with downpours and snow as a powerful storm system, the second of the holiday week, swept across the region Thursday.
A winter storm will soak San Diego tonight through Friday am.
In the mountains, snow flurries were falling on Christmas Eve, leaving a blanket of snow on the ground Thursday morning.
A Winter Storm Warning was issued from 4 a.m. to 6 p.m. Thursday due to the hazardous conditions.
Our Melissa Adan is reporting from Pine Valley off of Sunrise Highway where it is snowing and expected to snow all day long across San Diego County mountains.

title: 63-year-old man struck crossing Vista street, later dies
summary:
A 63-year-old man was struck by a vehicle on Vista street early Tuesday morning, and later died, a sheriff’s sergeant said.
The man was crossing East Vista Way near Townsite Drive about 5:45 a.m. when he was struck by a vehicle headed north, Sgt.
The victim was taken to a hospital, where he later died.
Alcohol does not appear to have been a factor in the incident, Gonzalez said.

title: 1 Stabbed, 1 Injured In Attack Near Chula Vista Intersection
summary:
CHULA VISTA, CA — One man was stabbed in the abdomen and another man suffered a minor laceration Wednesday morning when they were attacked by two groups of men from two separate cars after getting into an argument near a Chula Vista intersection, police said.
The altercation happened around 2 a.m. near Broadway and Flower Street, Chula Vista Police Lt. Scott Adkins said.
The two victims were walking northbound on Broadway when they got into an argument for unknown reasons with a motorist in a car near the intersection, Adkins said.
A fight ensued, during which one of the victims was stabbed in the lower abdomen and the other victim suffered a laceration to his abdomen, the lieutenant said.
No description of the suspects was immediately available, but the two cars were described as Volkswagen Jettas, one silver and one black.

title: 2019 Year in Review: San Diego's top stories
summary:
SAN DIEGO — As the decade comes to a close, we look back at some of San Diego's biggest stories in 2019.
One employee was fatally injured and two others were injured on November 6, 2019, during a shooting at Otay Mesa’s Church’s Chicken.
The San Diego man - believed to be a regular customer - opened fire after a Church’s Chicken employee refused to accept the counterfeit bill he was trying to use as payment.
Rep. Duncan Hunter pleaded guilty before a federal judge in San Diego on December 3, 2019 to misusing $150,000 in campaign funds for his own personal expenses.
While there were certainly more stories that could have made the list in 2019, these were some of the big events that happened in San Diego over the past year.

summary:

The Chula Vista Police Department is the first to use the Skydio 2 drones recently created in Redwood City, California.
We can often see if a suspect is armed, their exact clothing description, and see exactly where they are,” said Chula Vista Police Dept Capt.

title: Chula Vista Police Cite Five Drivers at Telegraph Canyon Road Checkpoint
summary:
Share This Article:Five citations were issued by Chula Vista police during an impaired driving and driver’s license checkpoint, officials said Sunday.
The checkpoint was set up in the 600 block of Telegraph Canyon Road and was in operation between 7 p.m. Saturday and 12:30 a.m. Sunday.
Of the 3,323 vehicles that traveled through the checkpoint, 1,007 vehicles were screened.
The checkpoint was funded by a grant from the California Office of Traffic Safety through the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: San Diego expected to be California’s ‘hottest’ home market in 2020, Zillow survey says
summary:
San Diego will be the hottest major home market for California in 2020, concludes a panel of experts in a Zillow study, but it won’t experience major gains as in past years.
They did not give an exact prediction of how much the median San Diego County home value would increase, which was about $600,650 as of November.
Instead, they rated the region on how likely it is to reach the national average of 2.8 percent.
While 39 percent of respondents thought San Diego County home values would under-perform compared to the national average, it was more extreme for other California markets.
Sixty-four percent predicted San Francisco would under-perform, 61 percent for San Jose, 55 percent in Los Angeles, 52 percent in Sacramento, and 47 percent in Riverside.

title: No charges filed against man arrested in connection with fatal 2019 Chula Vista stabbing
summary:
A 19-year-old arrested after allegedly stabbing a man during a struggle on a Chula Vista street last summer ultimately was not charged with the man’s death, authorities recently confirmed.
Dashawn Ignacio Mitchell told investigators that the July 24 stabbing of Jose Orozco, 28, happened during a robbery and had been self-defense, Chula Vista police Lt. Phil Collum said last week.
Evidence at the scene indicated some sort of struggle, Collum said.
The ensuing investigation, which included talking to witnesses and looking at security footage, led investigators to arrest Mitchell.
According to Collum, Mitchell said there had been an altercation and that he stabbed someone in self defense.

title: Cold storm brings rain, snow to county
summary:
Looking towards the ocean through car windshield on a rainy day rainPlease enable Javascript to watch this videoSAN DIEGO -- A winter storm brought rain and snowfall to San Diego County Thursday, with another storm slated to hit the region early next week following a brief reprieve this weekend.
The National Weather Service issued a winter storm warning that will be in effect until 6 p.m. in the county mountains, which are expected to receive another two to five inches of snow, primarily in areas above 3,500 feet.
By late afternoon, Oceanside and Escondido received the most rain over the past 24 hours at 1.63 inches.
While the wet conditions are expected to let up this weekend, another storm is on track to reach San Diego County on Monday and could bring light precipitation through Tuesday, forecasters said.
The NWS predicted as much as 10 inches of snow in San Diego County mountain areas at and above 6,000 feet during next week's storm.

title: Hard to believe, but San Diego got more rain than Seattle in November
summary:
Well, here’s a headline you don’t hear often:San Diego received more rain than Seattle during November.
And a small storm that will arrive on Tuesday night will get San Diego off to a good start in December as well.
The National Weather Service says that San Diego recorded 2.72 inches of precipitation in November, making it the 11th wettest November on record.
Local rainfall was 1.71 inches above normal.
Seattle recorded 1.71 inches of rain, making it the fourth driest November on record.

title: Safest, Least Safe CA Cities: WalletHub's 2019 List
summary:
CALIFORNIA — A new study by the personal finance website WalletHub ranked America's safest – and least safe – cities across the country.
The rankings included the 150 most populated cities in the United States, plus at least two of the most populated cities in each state.
Columbia, Maryland, ranked as the safest city in America, the researchers found, followed by Yonkers, New York, and Plano, Texas.
St. Louis, Missouri, ranked as the least safe city in the U.S.A total of 29 cities in California made the list, but only four cities ranked among the top 50 safest: Irvine, Fremont, Chula Vista and Rancho Cucamonga.
Each relevant metric was listed with its corresponding weight, and the cities were subsequently graded on a 100-point scale, with a score of 100 representing the safest possible city.

title: CBP denies access to doctors seeking flu vaccinations for migrant children
summary:
Alfred/The San Diego Union-Tribune)AdvertisementHolding signs saying “No more flu deaths” and “Children don’t belong in cages,” the doctors chanted and sang.
Some of them spoke about their own personal journey to the United States as undocumented migrant children.
The doctors noted in their letter that the flu mortality rate among migrant children in federal immigration custody was nine times higher than the general population last year.
The deaths came as the number of migrant children and families in custody reached a record high, some held for weeks before they were released or transferred to long-term detention facilities run by federal agencies that do provide vaccinations.
Last December, after two Guatemalan migrant children died in Border Patrol custody in the El Paso area, one from flu-related illness, Border Patrol officials promised to increase medical screenings, particularly for children.

title: Driver seriously injured in SR-76 crash near Pala
summary:
A driver suffered major injuries Monday night in a one-car crash east of Pala, authorities said.
Few details were immediately available, but the crash happened about 8:30 p.m. on east state Route 76 near Magee Road, according to a California Highway Patrol incident log.
The Honda Accord that crashed had “major front-end damage” and its “frame is buckled,” the Highway Patrol reported.
According to the CHP log, the driver sustained major injuries, though the injuries were not specified.
A California Highway Patrol officer investigates at the scene where a Honda Accord crashed and seriously injured the driver Monday night on state Route 76 in Pala.

title: For generations of San Diegans, December Nights has delivered unforgettable family experiences
summary:
Carolyn Wormser has vivid memories of participating in a longstanding San Diego holiday tradition with her young sons in tow.
“It was always such an enchanting and wonderful experience,” she recalls of those cozy holiday memories courtesy December Nights, the annual holiday extravaganza centered around Balboa Park.
Her official title is the city of San Diego’s Director of Special Events & Filming Department, the entity behind December Nights.
Online: For information on December Nights, including parking and transportation, go to sandiego.gov/december-nightsLeDonne is a freelance writer.
